scenes.location: AN IMPOSSIBLE EXPANSE OF MARYLAND FARMLAND

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wind rustles the endless field of corn, blows over th freshly mown meadow of soybeans, and magically sways a co trees. It's a Fall after-noon. A SUDDEN POUNDING OF GALLOPING HO breaks the peace and... A HORSE and RIDER burst between t of corn into the meadow.  They are running for their live

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rider is a bride -- a beautiful woman dressed in a disheveled wedding gown, it's train tattered and flying l knight's banner out behind her. This is MAGGIE CARPENTER. The horse is frothing and wild-eyed, like the bride, who to look behind her in terror.  The horse's labored breath mingles with Maggie's panicked gasps. We see a WEDDING BOUQUET fly into a ditch as the horse th on.  Maggie clings to the reins.  She looks as though she running from the devil himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing.

dialogues.speaker: IKE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hey, Fisher, pick up.  I have some column ideas I want to bounce off you. Not there?  Okay.  Listen I'm thinking of writing about those mind-numbing informercials that are always on. Ike walks out of his apartment building talking on cell p IKE (cont'd) What do you think?  Good idea, right? Boring, down to death, pointless -- It sucks. Ike yells at a CONSTRUCTION WORKER. IKE (cont'd) If you guys are here any longer, they're gonna make you sign a lease.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTRUCTION WORKER
dialogues.text: Your column should be so funny. Ike turns and walks down the street, talking into cell ph

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Okay, I was also thinking I might write about... He spots a RICH LADY with tons of diamonds getting out of Limousine, talking to a CHAUFFEUR.  He goes up to her. IKE (cont'd) Excuse me.  I was thinking of doing an article on limousines.  What would you say to people who never had a chance to drive in a limo? They walk up to her DOORMAN.

dialogues.speaker: LADY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I don't know any people like that. Ike walks off.  They stare at him as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike's talking on the phone to his friend's machine again.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Fisher?  Come on -- I know you're sitting there laughing at me.  Pick up. I want to run an idea past you. Ike continues walking now in the full panic of writer's b He pleads into his friend's answering machine as he walks IKE (cont'd) (into phone) I just could use someone to toss it back and forth with for a few minutes, get the juice flowing, help me.  I have an hour and twenty-seven minutes and fifty-two seconds.  Hello? He walks away from the t-shirt table towards the bar.  Th Vendor calls out to him.

dialogues.speaker: T-SHIRT VENDOR
dialogues.text: Hey, Ike, when are you going to put me in an article?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: When your t-shirts stop shrinking. Ike enters the bar.  The Woman drops the shirt she was ho and walks off with her children.  The T-shirt Vendor goes to selling his shirts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike sits at the bar speaking to an attractive Woman nearb MAN puts is USA Today on the bar and addresses the BARTEN

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I see photos of a lot of dead writers on these walls.  Got any living ones? I have a story to tell that could win one of them a Pulitzer. (then, with enthusiasm) Picture this, if you will.  A small town in Maryland, a sleepy little village, within that a hardware store... The Man continues speaking as Ike and the woman continue conversation.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: So what's in store for us in tomorrow's column?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: I don't know yet.  I'm kind of a last- minute man.  Ideas don't flow until an hour or two before deadline. The Woman gets up and begins throwing darts.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: (interrupting) This is very interesting.  You get your ideas for your column from life.  You start up a conversation with a woman in a bar, attack her choice of reading material, try and get a rise out of her while you contemplate whether or not she's worth hitting on.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: No, I can't hit on you until I get an idea. She starts throwing darts.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: That's flattering.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: No, you don't understand. The Woman goes to her bar stool, gathering her bag and le tip for the Bartender.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I think I do understand.  So my not responding to your baiting me will inspire one of those potential bitter diatribes you love to write about women and all the things we do to drive men crazy?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (taken aback) I don't write bitter diatribes about women... very often. She whacks him with a newspaper, then shakes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Only when the ideas aren't flowing, huh?  Well, it was very nice to meet you, one-minute man. The Woman leaves the bar.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (as she exits) That's last minute man. (then, louder) And it's the quality that counts.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: You know, for a good looking man, you strike out a lot.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I've seen much worse. The phone rings.  Te Bartender answers it as Ike sits bac his bar stool.  Ike grabs the woman's magazine that she l the bar and starts glancing at it.  The Man at the bar ha the whole thing. MAN (cont'd) I said, I've seen much worse. Ike looks at the Man with reservation.  The Man is George Swilling.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: The brush-off. Ike gets up and moves to the dart board.  He removes the MAN (cont'd) I've witnessed far more treacherous and nefarious exits than that.  At least she castigated you in private.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Not as private as I thought. Ike turns slightly, giving the man his back. IKE (cont'd) Kevin, you've got some napkins?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Writing or wiping?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Give me a pen. The Bartender gives him cocktail napkins and a pen.  Ike making notes.  Ike looks up from his writing.  The Man ge and starts throwing darts.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (throwing darts hard) Ah, come on.  They deserve it.  They love you, they hate you, they're hot, they're cold, they're high, they're low...

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: ... They're up, they're down.  It's really fun making this list with you, but I've got a column to go write.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Ike.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (undeterred) But you don't have a really superb idea! Well, there's a girl from my hometown you could write about. Ike moves to the Bartender and pays him.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: (to Man) Excuse me, we don't need any new ideas.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: She likes to dump grooms right at the altar.  They call her "The Runaway Bride". Both Ike and Bartender turn and stare.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: She performed the travesty seven or eight times.  Right at the altar she turns around and runs like hell. Bolts. Ike turns and heads for the door.  The Man calls after hi getting up from his stool without stopping his enthusiast story. MAN (cont'd) Adios.  Plows down the aisle, knocking old ladies out of her way like the running of the bulls at Pamplona.  And guess what?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: I give up.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: She has the next victim all lined up. She's twirling another body on the spit. Ike stops in his tracks.  He turns back around in spite o himself.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (beginning his story) Imagine if you will, a small town in Maryland...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike sits at his computer, cassette player with Miles Davi next to him as he types away reading his handiwork to him

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (reading) "Today is a day of profound introspection, I have been accused of using this column to direct bitter diatribes at the opposite sex!  This uncomfortable accusation has plunged me into at least fifteen minutes of serious reflection, from which I have emerged with the conclusion that, yes -- I traffic in female stereotypes."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FISHER walks through the main office reading the paper.

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: "But how can one blame me when every time I step out my front door I meet fresh proof that the female archetypes are alive and well?  Te mother, the virgin, the whore, the crone; they're elbowing you in the subway, stealing your cabs, and overwhelming you with perfume in elevators."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine at her desk reads aloud to herself.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: "But perhaps, in fairness to the fairer sex, I do need to broaden my horizon and add some new goddesses to the pantheon: I would like to nominate for deity..." Fisher hands a file to Elaine.

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: "... The cheerleader, the coed, and the man-eater, the last of which concerns me most today." Fisher leaves and we hold a USA Today sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Man comes out of the men's room reading the USA Today Kevin, the Bartender, stands on the bar reading the same article.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (reads) "To be fair, the man-eater isn't exactly new.  In Ancient Greece, this fearsome female was known as Erinys, the devouring death goddess.  In India, she is Kali, who likes to devour her boyfriend Shiva's entrails while her yoni devour his -- dot dot dot, never mind.  In Indonesia, the bloody-jawed man-eater is called Ragma..." Te Man sits at the bar near to the Bartender.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: You noticed these are all countries without cable. (then, continues reading) "... And in Hale, Maryland where she helps run the family hardware store. She is known as Miss Maggie Carpenter
(mispronounces) ".... AKA, the Runaway Bride."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WORKERS read the above article.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PEGGY and MRS. PRESSMAN exit the parlor and stroll down t street. (lowers her paper and reads.) PEGGY (cont'd) "... And in Hale, Maryland where she helps run the family hardware store." (to the Women) We have to go to Maggie.  Cindy, mind the shop. (exits salon; continues reading) "... She is known as Miss Maggie Carpenter, AKA, the Runaway Bride."

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PRESSMAN
dialogues.text: Holy moly. The older one, Mrs. Pressman, listens with a pained expre as the younger one, Peggy, continues to read the column a Neither one can believe what they're reading.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: (reads) "What is unusual about Miss Carpenter is that she likes to dress her men up as grooms before she devours them.  She has already disemboweled six in a row by leaving them at the altar."... I can't ready anymore.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PRESSMAN
dialogues.text: (takes paper from her, reads) "And her ritual feast continues as she prepares to make a sacrifice out of the seventh fiance.  So all bets are on and we hope that this boomerang bride isn't honeymooning with Las Vegas odds makers because many predict that this girl is out of there before the race... before the rice hits the ground" (then) Holy moly. Peggy and Mrs. Pressman step into a hardware store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy and Mrs. Pressman enter, worried.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PRESSMAN
dialogues.text: You tell Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: No, you tell her.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PRESSMAN
dialogues.text: No, no.  You're her best friend.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PRESSMAN
dialogues.text: (holding her newspaper) You know, it's just possible that she hasn't read this yet.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PRESSMAN
dialogues.text: Maybe she hasn't read the paper... On the counter, they see a copy of USA Today opened to th article about Maggie. MRS. PRESSMAN (cont'd) ... Or not! We follow MAGGIE down the back stairs inside The Hale Har Store, the prettiest, most welcoming shop of its kind any in small town USA.  Somehow the place ha taken on the spi the owner's daughter; both stop and shop-girl radiate bri charm, and possibility.  Maggie comes down steps with a f handle and goes to an elderly customer, MR. PAXTON.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (bright) Here we go!  One antique hot water handle with the "HOT" still on it, guaranteed to fit any American Standard cast iron tub with a four-inch center made between 1924 and 1938.  In other words, I think you're out of the doghouse with Mrs. Paxton.

dialogues.speaker: MR. PAXTON
dialogues.text: (amazed) Hallelujah.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Alright, Mr. Paxton, I'll put it on your account. Maggie rounds the bend, another customer, EARL, stands by paint machine.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (walking past customer) You don't need an air conditioner, Earl, you just need an attic fan -- There's more in the back. Maggie steps behind the front counter of the store and ta account book out.  Her voice trails off as she sees the d expression on the faces of her friends. MAGGIE (cont'd) What? Peggy nervously mentions the newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: (delicate) So -- Mag -- you've seen this, huh?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (serious) Yes, I've seen it.  And I have to say it's the rudest and most offensive... joke anybody's ever played on me! To their amazement, Maggie starts smiling. MAGGIE (cont'd) You guys!  How long did this take you? Maggie stays amused. MAGGIE (cont'd) Where'd you get this done? (laughing) You creeps!  I should disinvite you! And why did you say seven times?  This is four.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Uh, Maggie, you told us to bachelorette jokes, so we didn't... Maggie looks at the stricken face of her friends.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PRESSMAN
dialogues.text: Holy moly. Peggy looks like she is going to cry with sympathy for Ma Maggie is starting to feel uncomfortable.  She looks down dubiously, at the paper.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Um, you know, now would be a good moment to tell me this is fake. (no response) It won't be funny if you drag it out. Okay? (no response) Okay, well... I mean, I can find out... Real newspapers smear.  Phoney papers don't. She picks up the paper and brushes it against her apron, an INK SMEAR!! She nearly kneels over. MAGGIE (cont'd) (sitting) Bag. Peggy and Mrs. Pressman immediately spring to her side. give her a bag to breathe in.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PRESSMAN
dialogues.text: Bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Maggie kickboxing in anger.  The radio is on.  She suddenly stops, yanks Ike's article off the wall, leaves workout area and goes to her desk.

dialogues.speaker: DESK AREA
dialogues.text: She turns off the radio and begins to type her letter.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "Dear Editor..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Maggie's VOICE-OVER continues to read her letter, we t a Manhattan busy day.  It is big, loud, and anonymous. MAGGIE (V.O.; cont'd) "Greeting from the sticks!  Perhaps you believe that a rural education is focused mainly on hog calling and tractor maintenance rather than reading. Why else would you print a piece of fiction about me and call it fact?" Te CAMERA FINDS Ike, striding across a busy street, dodgi taxies.  A WOMAN smacks him with a newspaper.  He passes TRAFFIC OFFICER, then a hot dog stand.  He greets and pas FALAFEL VENDOR.  THE CAMERA PANS to a USA Today Truck. MAGGIE (V.O.; cont'd) "I suppose Mr. Graham was too busy thinking us slanderous statements about how I dump men for kicks to bother with something silly like accuracy in reporting.  Which is understandable, because with a "man-eater" like me on the loose, who has time to check facts?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He passes regular GUYS who cheer him. MAGGIE (V.O.; cont'd) "Still, we cannibalistic queens can get pretty cranky when we see things in print that hurt our feelings, like that we deliberately abandon fiances with malice aforethought."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He enters the newspaper building, going to Ellie's office

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks through the crowded city room.  His arrival attr lot of attention from his CO-WORKERS.  Ike seems a little surprised, but he's pleased. MAGGIE (V.O.; cont'd) "That's why I was surprised to find Mr. Graham's editor was a woman. Call me a sentimental fool, but I sort of hoped we man-eater could stick together." Ike works his way down the hall to the editor's office. Ike greets various workers.  He steps up to the editor's secretary, ELAINE.  She doesn't smile.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (to Elaine) I'll put in a good word for you.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: No, no, don't mention my name in there.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Why? A buzz.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: You can go in now. Ike goes into Ellie's office.  Elaine picks up her phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLIE is that editor.  Stylish and successful looking, sh about Ike's age.  Ellie sits behind a big desk with a sco her pretty face.  Her casual-looking husband, Fisher, sit nonchalantly on the arm of the couch.  Ike enters as Elli Maggie's letter.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (reading letter) "Anyway, I'm just dropping you big city folk this little note to say that I have thought of a ritual sacrifice that would satisfy my current appetite: Ike Graham's column on a platter.  Yours truly, Maggie Carpenter.  P.S. -- I have inclosed a list of the gross factual misrepresentations in your article.  There are fifteen." Ike sits as Ellie puts the letter down and takes off her

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (chuckles as he sits) Fully.  I like her.  She has wit.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: I left four messages.  You don't return my calls.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: So?  I never returned your calls, even when we were married.  And what's Fisher doing here anyway? Fisher gets and places a photo of the cat on a bookshelf way to the other side of the room.

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: Ellie asked me to come down to offer moral support.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Since when does Ellie need moral supp--

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: -- It's for you, Ike.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Journalism lesson number one.  If you fabricate your facts, you get fired. Ellie pushes USA Today lawyer's letter across the desk fo to read.  Ike picks it up and skims the letter.  His face impassive as stone.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Lesson number two.  Never work for your former spouse.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: That's not nothing to do with it.  You cooked this story up and you know it.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: I didn't cook up a story.  I had a source.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Someone reliable, I'm sure.  A booze- hound in a bar?

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: In vino veritas.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Don't knock drunk guys in bars.  Drunk guys in bars are good.  It means they're not driving. Ike gets up and stands near Ellie, making his point. IKE (cont'd) Besides, I'm a columnist.  This is what columnists are supposed to do.  This is what you like.  We push, we stretch, we go out on a limo.  That's what makes me good!

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: No, that's what makes you unemployed.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: I merely write the stuff.  You're the one that serves it up. Ike puts down the letter and puts his glasses back into h pocket.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Not anymore.  I have to draw the line. (pushing a piece of paper) She sent us this list.  Our lawyers say it's actionable. Ellie hands Ike Maggie's list.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (scoffs) Lawyers. (glances at list) I don't know, Ellie -- Firing me is going to be very tough on you.  It's going to be hard to get over.  There will be therapy bills for you.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (shrugs) I already made an appointment for later today.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (putting the list down, standing) See?  You want custody of my job? ... Why not just consider my wrist slapped and call me when you feel I've served my time?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Ike.  This is permanent. Fisher winces and looks away.  Ike and Ellie look at each for a sober moment. ELLIE (V.O.; cont'd) If you go quietly, I'll get you severance pay. Ellie fidgets with her toy rake, then Ike heads for the d He laughs a little at the painful truth of her words and out.  Ellie collapses back in her chair.  Fisher goes to rubs her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike rides sadly on the back of a forklift, gets off and w out.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: A train goes by.  A modest clapboard house with a porch. entrances.  A PAPERBOY tosses a paper onto the lawn in fr the house.  The front door opens and Maggie appears fresh bed, wearing only a jacket and panties.  Heedless of bein this way, she scampers out to the sidewalk to pick up her delivered paper:  USA Today.  She tears off the plastic b rips into it, looking for her letter.  She finds it.  A s her face, then she scampers back into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie skips back into her house which she shares with Fa and Grandma.  A cozy and eclectic place creatively furnis a shoe-string.  She rushes into:  KITCHEN WHERE BOB KELLY fiance #4, is packing cans into a backpack.  Bob, 38, has pleasant face and a body that is almost shockingly buff. wearing a T-shirt that reads: "Mountaineers Do It Against Wall.", Maggie dances over, waving the paper and singing.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: She canned him, she canned him... Bob test the weight of the backpack adding dehydrate food

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Come here, Mag, and try this on. Maggie puts the paper on the kitchen counter and starts t aloud, paying no mind to Bob, who is sticking her arms th the straps of the backpack.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Listen: "Dear Ms. Carpenter, I apologize to you for this unfortunate matter.  Ike Graham's column will no longer be appearing in this paper. Best of luck in you upcoming marriage!" Bob continues to hold up the weight of the backpack as he it onto Maggie's shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: That-a-girl!  You sacked him. (checking pack) This is the weight of the pack you're going to have to carry in the Himalayas. Tell me if it's too heavy. Bob lets go and Maggie FALLS BACKWARD, disappearing behin counter, and hitting the floor, with a THUD.  Bob looks d her.  Maggie's voice rises from the floor behind the coun MAGGIE (o.s.) It's a little... It's a little heavy... Help me, baby. Bob has no answer.  He reaches a hand down.  He yelps as pulls him down on top of her, out of frame.  We HEAR them and kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fisher uses the dock for a photo shoot featuring men and in evening and formal wear from Escada for G.Q.  Fisher i actually shooting the camera, but rather supervising it. Fisher claps his hands and calls the models to attention. he goes onto the stage and sets the models in their posit FISHER (cont'd) Remember, we are putting the "fun" back into formal. (to Ike) I just say that for the agency guys.  I don't even know what that means.  Now follow me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elevator doors open.  Ike and Fisher exit and walk toward coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: Ike, I really liked the Runaway Bride piece, and since I do freelance stuff for G.Q., I'm in a different position now...

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: What are you trying to say to me, Fish? They stop walking.

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: Vindication.  How would you like to get some?  A chance to prove that, though your facts weren't entirely straight, your theory was correct.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (hiding his hope) The real story on Miss Carpenter.

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: All the gory details. They start walking again.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (excited) The anatomy of the black widow spider of Maryland.

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: It wouldn't be a bad way to get you back into writing feature pieces again.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (enthusiastically) This is good.  It is a good story, Fish. They stop at the coffee table and grab something to eat.

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: (nods) If she runs, then it's a cover story. All true.  All accurate.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (confesses) Okay, you were right.  I hated my column, but I can do this assignment.

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: Then you've got it.  If you leave tomorrow for the hinterlands, you'll have plenty of time before her next wedding trot.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: "Paid vindication"  That's what I call justice.

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: Justice, yes.  Paid, I don't know. They like the idea, but my hands are tied with budget restraints.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: But I'll get my normal fee, right? He walks away.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: You want me to do it on spec?! He follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Ike driving down the highway.  The car sputters a as he and Fisher continue their conversation in voice-ove needed by the editor.)

dialogues.speaker: FISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Don't say "spec" like it's a dirty word. Nobody ever paid Shakespeare to write a play!  Plato never got a book advance...

dialogues.speaker: IKE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Oh yeah!  I happen to know from reliable sources that Nietzche got expenses and a rental car. We hear Fisher laugh. IKE (V.O.; cont'd) I'm going to make this work, Fish.  I'm going to do it! Ike's car drives into Hale, passing a billboard reading, "Welcome to Hale."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike drives down picturesque Main Street.  He passes Hale Hardware.  Sign says: "At Curl.  Be back soon."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BARBERSHOP QUARTET is singing in front of the only hote town.  Ike pulls up and goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike has checked into the Atlantic Hotel.  The clerk, LEE, him his key.  Ike asks about room service and the restaur An OLDER WOMAN asks him if he plays bridge as he goes up stairs to his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike exits his hotel as the Barber Shop Quartet finishes s "Camptown Races." He now walks down the charming main artery of the town, l exactly like what he is:  a cynical New York out of his e on sunny Main Street, USA.  KIDS ride by on bikes, stream balloons behind them.  A balloon hits Ike on the face.  A crosses the street, he mutters into his tape recorder:

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: I think I'm in Maryberry. Flags hang on all the storefronts and the place sparkles wholesome attitudes as PEOPLE greet each other familiarly comes to beauty parlor called "Curl Up and Dye".  The pla doing business and crowded with WOMEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cindy, the manicurist, does Mrs. Pressman's nails.  Maggi on the floor next to Peggy's salon chair, fixing the base barber chair.  She tightens a screw and looks up, satisfi Cindy's dog is on the floor near Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Cindy, you better 86 Sprout.  He seems to be enjoying the petroleum distillates. Cindy rolls over in her chair, picks up her dog and rolls to her station.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: That's it.  Back to obedience school.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (to Peggy) Okay -- have a seat... gently, carefully. Peggy sits in the chair.  Maggie spins her around and aro

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: (delighted as she spins) You're a goddess!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I didn't even need to change this gasket, just put in a little hydraulic fluid.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Stop it.  When you talk like that, I get turned on and it frightens me. JUST THEN.  Ike enters the salon, taking off his sunglass Peggy hops off the chair.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Hello.  I'm looking for Maggie Carpenter.  There was a sign at the hardware store across the street...

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Are you a reporter? It's a little early in the game for Ike to be thrown off

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (shocked) What?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: (eyeing his loafers) It's been our experience that anyone with some sort of gewgaw on his loafers ends up being another big city reporter wanting to interview Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: About her upcoming wedding and all.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: No, about her getting that asshole from New York fired. Ike smiles down at his loafers and shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: I am just such a reporter.  And you are?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Peggy Phleming.  Not the ice skater. Peggy steps aside.  Ike moves toward Cindy and Mrs. Press

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: And who are these lovely ladies? Te ladies shake his hand and introduce themselves.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Cindy.  Maggie's unmarried cousin.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PRESSMAN
dialogues.text: Mrs. Pressman.  No relation.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: And you are?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (turning toward her) Looking for Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Yep.  Maggie -- Someone to see you. Maggie looks over from her sitting position on the floor. gives Ike the once-over, focusing on the shoes.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (yelling to Peggy) Reporter?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Yup! Ike crouches to see Maggie on the floor just as she rises feet.  Ike straightens up.  For a moment, he is thrown by beauty and intelligent eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I hope you have a different angle. It's pretty much all been covered.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Originality is my speciality.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Excellent.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Hold on -- Nobody interviews Maggie in here unless they're getting haircut.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: She's the boss.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Sorry, no.  I just got one.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PRESSMAN
dialogues.text: (to Ike) Excuse me, sir.  I have an actual fact for you.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (steps to Mrs. Pressman) Yes, Mrs. Pressman.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PRESSMAN
dialogues.text: It's her fourth time to the altar, you know.  Not seven like they said.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: I know.  Tell me something.  Do you think she's going to make it all the way this time? During the Ike/Mrs. Pressman exchange, Maggie looks at Ik There's something familiar about him.  She looks over at and beckons her to a copy of Ike's column affixed to a mi A goatee and horns, have been scrawled on Ike's byline pi He's been "devilized".  Peggy coughs as she recognizes Ik the newspaper clipping.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: She swallowed her gun. Mrs. Pressman continues her story to Ike.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PRESSMAN
dialogues.text: I'm not sure.  Mr. Schullian runs the newsstand, he's our local bookie, you know, he's giving eight to one odds she won't.  He says she's so famous now, maybe Vegas will give odds on her.  I'm going to wait to hear what the pros say.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Good fact.  Well, you let me know.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PRESSMAN
dialogues.text: Oh, I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie indicates column to Peggy.  She looks over at the the shop used to wash and dye hair.  There's a sink, stoo cabinet affixed to the wall above sink, which holds vario shampoos and hair dyes.  Maggie gets an idea.  Maggie and step forward toward Ike.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Well, instead of a haircut, how about a wash?  You know, get all that city grit out of it.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: You'll answer my questions? Maggie nods affirmatively. IKE (cont'd) (removing his jacket) Fine.  You wash, I'll ask the questions.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Great. Ike hands Peggy his jacket.  A mystified Peggy leads Ike sink.  While she does this...

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Have a seat.  Peggy, why don't you give him the special treatment that strengthens the follicles. Ike sits in the chair near the sink.  Maggie shakes out a and puts it around Ike. MAGGIE (cont'd) So, what do you want to know? Ike leans and rests his head on the sink.  Peggy bends ov and wets his hair.  She grabs various hair coloring produ

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Getting nervous?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Nervous?  Not at all!  No.  I've never been more certain in my life.  Except -- I am having all kinds of weird dreams. Ike pulls the cloth down from over his face.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Weird dreams?  You're going to tell me about them?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: (calming) Let's just put this back here for the aromatherapy. Peggy recovers his face, then continues to fuss with the coloring products.  Maggie helps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike sits with a towel over his head as Peggy blow-dries t of his head.  His back is to the mirror, his body faces M Cindy does her own nails as Mrs. Pressman scratches off l tickets.  The dog, Sprout, sits in is basket.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: In another one... PETE, wearing a hat, comes in the front door of the salon

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Hey, Pete, I'll be right with you. Ike peeks out from under his towel as Maggie continues.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I'm inside the church.  Everyone I know is there, only they're not really them. They're like Frankenstein monsters, but without the bolts coming out of their necks.  It's all very "Night of the Living Dead".  And here's the creepiest part -- I look down at my dress and it's red.  I mean, I have no idea what it means.  Red's not my color! Ike listens intently and stares steadily into her eyes. removes the towel.  His hair is divided into equal parts dyed orange and red. MAGGIE (cont'd) So what do you think? Ike stares back at her, the tickle of suspicion creeping spine.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: I think you'd look good in red.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: No, she's talking about your hair. Maggie swivels his chair so that Ike faces the mirror.  I looks at his brightly colored hair.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You're all ready for football season, Mr. Graham. Ike stares at his hair in total confusion.  With icy calm rises from his chair and primps the end of his hair as if it the finishing touches.  Then he sees his defaced newsp clipping and all becomes clear.  He picks up the article shows it to everyone.  Ike does a slow burn.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Yes, I think I nailed the personality profile of the women of Hale. Ike turns and puts the clipping up on the mirror. IKE (cont'd) (to Peggy) My jacket, please. Peggy hands him his jacket. IKE (cont'd) (sarcastically) Thank you. Ike moves toward the door.  He spots Pete. IKE (cont'd) (putting on jacket; to Pete) Excuse me, Pete, do you know a place that sells shampoo... Strong shampoo?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Doc's Pharmacy.  Third and Elm.  Tell him Pete sent you.  Want my hat?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: No thanks. Ike smiles at Maggie and exits.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (to Peggy) He seems crabby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In front of beauty salon, Maggie follows Ike out.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: If you're looking for Elm Street, it's that way. She puts on her sunglasses.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Thank you. He walks the other way.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: If you came down here in the pursuit of happiness, you might as well go back. Because you can't make me feel bad. She stops walking and turns to Ike.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: I'm not here to make you feel bad.  I'm here for vindication.  In my heart...

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You have one? Ike walks back to Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: I feel I'm right about you.  You got me fired, lady.  You destroyed my reputation and you screwed up my hair. You chew men up, spit them out and loved it.  And I'm down here to satisfy myself on that point. PASSERSBY stare at Ike's hair and giggle.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Did something happen to make you care about reality?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Yes.  Conviction.  Conviction that I'm onto the truth.  You're going to do the same thing to "poor bastard number four" that you did to the last three.  You're going to run again.  And I'm not leaving until you do.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You're going to be very disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: We'll see.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I'd love to stay and chat, but I've got to get back to work.  I still have my job. He stares at her for a beat, stung by her words.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I have nothing to hide, Mr. Graham. Talk to whoever you want.  You might actually stumble upon a fact or two. Maggie walks away.  Ike walks a few steps and stops at a a bike.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Hey, kid, I'll give you ten bucks for your hat. Kid agrees.  Ike puts the hat on and starts to cross the An OLD WOMAN walks by and hits him with a newspaper.  Ike stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie pulls into the driveway in her truck.  She's in a mood as she walks right in the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, Walter, and Maggie's GRANDMOTHER JULIA sit in the li room.  Grandma is sewing one of Maggie's wedding veils. drinks wine, Ike wears a hat.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: You know, when I only see one dog, I know I've had too much to drink. Te family dog, Skipper, sits near a ceramic dog table.  M smiles as she walks in the front door and puts down her t and bag.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You'll never guess who came crawling into town with his tail between his legs. IKE (o.s.) Who? Maggie enters the parlor to see Ike smiling evilly from h on the couch. IKE (cont'd) (innocently) Hello, Maggie.  I just came by to apologize to your family. (looks to Walter) When I'm wrong, I'm wrong.  I pushed a story.  I made a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: In other words -- he's only human.  An he brought us a bottle of wine. Raises the bottle to Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: They made me put my hat back on.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah.  Scared the hell out of Skipper.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You've got to be kidding me. Maggie stares at them both.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (enjoying the moment) No, no, you should have seen Skipper. (then, imitates growling) It wasn't that funny. Maggie gives him a look that says, "You are not absolved. smiles stiffly, looking back at Ike.  She then sits on th of Bob's chair and puts her arm on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: So, the forces of good and evil have already met. Maggie takes the wine bottle from the table next to Walte snaps a look to Bob, who follows her.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I'll help you take into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDMA JULIA
dialogues.text: Check on the crabs, Bob. We overhear them murmuring in annoyed tones about the wed plans as they exit... Walter puts down his drink.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Gee, I hope they don't have a fight out there.  You don't think they'll call it off...?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Well, wedding cake freezes.  This we know.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: You know, your daughter seems... Ike notices that he's been sewn to the veil.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDMA JULIA
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: That's okay, Grandma. Grandma cuts the thread and separates the veil from Ike's IKE (cont'd) (continuing his thought) ... Like such a lovely girl. Walter points to a portrait painting on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Like her mother.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (seeing the portrait) Ah, beautiful. (gets up to admire the portrait) I just can't see her leaving multiple grooms in the dust like that.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDMA JULIA
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, you can.  She's has 'em all on tape.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: She has a tape?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: (good-natured) Yeah.  Lee at the hotel videos wedding. I mean Maggie didn't know she was going to make the hundred-yard dash. Walter gestures to a pile of video cassettes on the bookc Ike checks on the tapes.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Dad's fishing trip, Grandma's knee operation, Grandma's birthday...

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Gotta tell you this about my daughter. My daughter makes real good time, even in a long dress and heels.  Maggie may not be Hale's longest running joke, but she certainly is the fastest. Walter cracks up.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDMA JULIA
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) Ha ha. CLOSE ON:  A tape.  It reads: "Maggie I, II, III."  Ike's interest is more than piqued.  Ike picks it up.  They get go to the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family dog, Skipper, steals food from the table.  Wal scolds him.  Walter whacks his crab with his hammer and I copies him. WALTER (cont'd) Emma and I were only blessed with one child, not for lacking of trying.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: This is good, Dad, don't leave anything out. Ike's hammer flies out of his hand.  He goes to pick it u

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: So I've come to see it as a bonus, really, that we've been able to plan, and pay for, so many weddings.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Not this one.  This one's on me. Walter reacts.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: That's fair.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Despite what you think, I don't do it on purpose.  And I have no intention of doing it again.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: That's right, Maggie.  Just keep your eye on the ball. Ike raises his eyebrows in question.  Bob explains. BOB (cont'd) Sports psychology.  It was my major in college.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Ahh.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (false modesty) I'm the town's unofficial fitness trainer.  Big advocate of the mind and body combining for success.  You could say or you can quote me, I'm a glass half full king of guy.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (boasting) Bob's the head of the P.E. department at the high school.  And he coaches the football team.  And he's climbed Everest. To Maggie's satisfaction, Ike shoots Bob a look of begrud respect.  Nobody who's been up Everest is a total clown.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (impressed) Everest.  Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Twice...

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (sticking it to Ike) Without oxygen...

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: My girl likes to brag about me. Bob and Maggie kiss Ike two little love-birds. BOB (cont'd) I'm taking her trekking on Annapurna on our honeymoon. Ike is highly amused.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: How romantic.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (sharply) We think so.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Nothing like sharing your nuptial bed with two Sherpas and a yak. Walter cracks up, Maggie shoots Ike a look.  He smiles ba

dialogues.speaker: TELEPHONE CONVERSATION
dialogues.text: Fisher and Ellie are exercising.  Fisher is on a cycle ma Ellie does yoga stretches.  Ike sits back on the couch, p his glasses and watches a video taped wedding playing on screen.  Superimposed titles read "Brian Norris wedding."

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (to Fisher; into phone) You won't believe what I'm looking at, Fisher.  A videotape of all three train wrecks.

dialogues.speaker: THE TV
dialogues.text: Two flower girls and Peggy enter a crowded church where t groom, Brian, and his best man wait at the altar. Now we see Maggie come down the aisle, then walk past the We see Maggie move away another aisle and out of the chur SHOCKED WEDDING GUESTS rise in horror, as she runs from t first wedding.  She drags the train boy up the second ais she leaves.  Ike hangs up.  He gets up to pick up the rem then sits back down to watch. The tape fast-forwards to the next wedding.  Now Ike is l at a much more relaxed, hipper, backyard wedding.  It say "Gill Chavez Wedding".  He hits the fast-forward button (sometimes slowing down).

dialogues.speaker: ON TV
dialogues.text: We see the Carpenter's backyard.  It is Gill and Maggie's wedding day.  The yard is crowded with a MIXTURE of Hells Angels-types, Deadheads and townspeople.  The "altar" is platform against the back fence. Gill is waiting on the platform with a rock combo playing Grateful Dead-type music.  He makes an introductory speec Maggie steps out onto the back porch.  She's beautiful in hippie-type wedding ensemble.  She walks with her father trampoline.  We can see her tattoo.  She jumps on the tra then dives into the crowd.  They watch her and body surf over their heads to the back fence. As she hits the stage, she looks at Peggy and Gill, then to go.  She jumps off the stage and runs up to a passing a dirt bike.  She jumps on and turns and waves as she rid away.  During the video, Ike scribbles: "Gill Chavez".  M goes off on dirt bike.  The tape fast-forwards to the las Maggie's fiascoes.

dialogues.speaker: ON IKE'STV
dialogues.text: He now sees the third wedding.  It's outdoors, in a tree area, MUSICIANS plays.  Ike laughs as he discovers that M approaches the altar on horseback, in a simple white dres wearing a crown of flowers.  The Maid Marian look.  Ike s tape. ON TV:  IT SAYS, "GEORGE SWILLING WEDDING". As Maggie rides down the aisle, suddenly the horse whinni Maggie has kicked it in the shins.  It rears and bolts, galloping off with the bride.  Ike FREEZE FRAMES the tape image of Maggie, hair blowing.  Although she is panic-str her soul seems to shine through in tat single frame.  As stares at her, the smirk fades from his face.  He just lo her, allowing himself to see her expression, her eyes.  H help it. She gets to him.  Ike gets a restless look on his face. stares closely.  The groom is George from the bar.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Kamikaze!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing.  High angle wide shot of a bakery in Hale. exits a neighboring shop and walks down the block.  He pa front of the bakery to take a look at Maggie's truck.  As does, a middle-aged Black WOMAN walks by and whacks him w newspaper.  Ike is stunned as she walks off.  He turns to sitting on a bench.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Did you see that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a group of plastic grooms and brides on a counte MRS. TROUT is behind the counter helping Maggie with a se of grooms for her wedding cake.  The groom figures are sp on the counter.  All sizes and colors, some attached to b some solo, some tuxes, some in dinner jackets.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. TROUT
dialogues.text: This one's very popular, but oh, you've used this one before... Brian.  But I like the white dinner jacket.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No, he's no good.  Too blond.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. TROUT
dialogues.text: (picks up another) We'll go with total traditional.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Too dark. Then, Ike comes up behind her as she discards another gro

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: But he's got the Bobster's eyes. Maggie cringes at the sound of Ike's voice. IKE (cont'd) No -- the Bobster's eyes are closer set. She ignores him and continues her search. IKE (cont'd) (to Mrs. Trout) Could I have two coffees, please?  And what is that wonderful smell? (seeing the cinnamon rolls) I'll have two of those delicious looking cinnamon rolls.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. TROUT
dialogues.text: Sure. (picking up a miniature bride) Here, Maggie.  I think this makes the best you. Mrs. Trout steps away to get his order.  Ike moves to the side of Maggie and picks up the bride and groom figure.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Let's see... Excuse me, isn't that cute? Ahh... He makes the bride figure repeatedly knock the groom figu the head and run away screaming. IKE (cont'd) Bam, bam, bam, bam, bam!  Oh, help me! Help me!  Yup!  That's her all right. Mrs. Trout just about bursts a gut laughing.  Maggie take bride from Ike coldly.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. TROUT
dialogues.text: You must be that Mr. Graham fellow. Ike turns and goes to her.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Yes, I am.  And who are you?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. TROUT
dialogues.text: Betty Trout.  Five dollars.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (as he pays) Oh, Betty.  I take it you're going to be making the wedding cake and they say you're throwing --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. TROUT
dialogues.text: (interrupting) -- The luau for Maggie. She starts picking lint off his sleeve and buttons his cu

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (all smiles for Mrs. Trout) Grandma made me the cutest outfit.  I can't wait to show it to you.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (cynical delight) A pre-wedding luau?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. TROUT
dialogues.text: Yes.  My husband and I love luaus. It'll be fun. Mrs. Trout turns and grabs Ike's bag containing two coffe

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Fun?  Fun isn't the word. Mrs. Trout beams.  Maggie understands his answer a little Mrs. Trout hands Ike his items and he pays.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. TROUT
dialogues.text: If you're still in town, you should stop by.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No, I'm sure he doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (to Mrs. Trout) Actually, I would love to come. (taps her service bell) Thank you.  Thank you so much. Maggie steps over, carrying her bride and groom figure ch

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Is that what you're going to do now? Follow me around everywhere I go? Ike smiles at Maggie enigmatically as he picks up his ord heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: No. He starts to leave with his bag.  Mrs. Trout stops him.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. TROUT
dialogues.text: (handing him the other bag) Your two cinnamon rolls.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Bye, Betty.  Thanks. He leaves.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: He's not a nice person. Maggie hands Mrs. Trout her bride and broom figures.  Mag looks at Mrs. Trout, suddenly nervous.  She dashes out. Trout imitates Ike bamming the bride and groom, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Various High School SPORTS TEAMS practice.  Maggie stride the football field, a scowl on her face.  A few HIGH SCHO FOOTBALL PLAYERS job past Maggie, doing laps.  A boy, KEN calls out to her affectionately as she passes.  One of th DENNIS, slows his pace to run alongside Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: (playful) Maggie, don't marry Coach!  Marry me. I love you.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You're jail bait, Dennis.  Go away. Run your laps.  Go. Go. Dennis runs on as Maggie continues toward her goal: Bob a standing together on the other side of the field.

dialogues.speaker: BOB AND IKE
dialogues.text: They're both standing on the blocking sled.  Wave after w VARSITY FOOTBALL PLAYERS ram into the sled and drive it a the field with both Ike and Bob on top of it.  Ike is mun one of the cinnamon rolls as Bob pushes the KIDS.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Drive!  Drive!  From your hips, get low, get low, get low.  Next! Ike smiles broadly atop of the sled as he sees Maggie approaching, looking mighty peeved.  He nudges Bob and po Maggie.  Bob lights up at the sight of her. BOB (cont'd) Good job, gentlemen... Special teams. The football players move away from the sled.  Bob moves Maggie, leaves Ike alone. BOB (cont'd) (to Maggie) Hey, honey! Bob kisses and embraces Maggie.  She doesn't see Ike imme then:

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (indicating Ike) What is he up to now?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Ike just came by to check out the team.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: And talk about you. Ike grins and shows Maggie the notes in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Bob -- are you making friends with this man?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I'm just bragging about how great you are.  I'm the luckiest man alive. Bob grabs Maggie around the waist and smooches her adorin Maggie scowls at Ike.  He nods, all charm.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Well -- I've got to get moving -- lot of work to do today!  I'll see you two love-birds later. Ike leaves.  Bob calls after him.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: See you at the wedding.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: You bet ya, Coach. Maggie is aghast.  She stares at Bob.  Ike joins in behin of peppy cheerleaders.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: At the wedding?  You invite him?  Bob, don't you realize he's writing another article about me?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Sure I do.  But the bet defense is a good offense, right?  You're not going to let your opponent throw you off your game.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You don't understand this guy.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Let him come to the wedding.  You're not running, right?  Say it. "I'm not..."

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (irritably) I'm not running.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: So if you're not running and Ike Graham is there to see it, then any article he writes has got to have a happy ending, right?  All we're doing is turning lemon into lemonade.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I've got news for you.  No amount of sugar and water is going to turn like Graham into something you want to take on a picnic. Bob gives Maggie a big hug.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Where's that homemade sunshine? Bob blows his whistle, then puts Maggie on the football s BOB (cont'd) I want you boys to take my princess on the ride of her life... Honey, tell 'em where you parked your car. Maggie screams as the boys push her down the football fie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie kneels, hands folded reverently.  The booth's grat before her.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Bless me, Father, for I have sinned. My last confession was... ahh... She tries to recall. MAGGIE (cont'd) ... Anyway, I have sort of a technical question here.  I've been having -- bad thoughts.  I mean, really bad thoughts ...

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Of an impure nature?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No -- like -- I'm having a problem with that whole turn-the-other-cheek concept. I want revenge.  I want to destroy this guy's life, career, everything. On the sin scale, how big is that?  I mean, can I "Hail Mary" my way out of it?

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Child, any sin in one's heart is...

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (impatient) The name's Maggie.  It wasn't this side of ten years ago that you had your tongue down my throat.  So don't call me "child", Brian.  It annoys me.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST/ BRIAN
dialogues.text: Now don't get upset. Brian closes the confessional window and exits

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (still inside the booth) Brian, open up.  Don't ignore me. Brian leans into her confessional.  She steps out to join

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: You're not even Catholic, Maggie -- you really shouldn't come to confession. He's a nice looking and gentle man.  They regard each oth beat.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.  I'm just so stressed out about that slime-ball reporter being in town.  I jus had to come warn you he might show up here and start asking you all kinds of ridiculous questions. Brian moves away.  Maggie follows and sits in a nearby pe

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Actually, he only asked me one ridiculous question.  The rest weren't so bad.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (sliding along the pew) What?  You talked to him!  Did you tell him we dated before you were a priest?

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, I'm sure I only did you good, Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What did he ask? A woman, MRS. MURPHY, rushes in.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MURPHY
dialogues.text: Father, am I too late?

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: No, no.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MURPHY
dialogues.text: It won't take long.  Jus two venials. The woman goes into the confessional booth to wait.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Only respectful things.  What did we have in common back then... What kind of music did you like... Did you ruin my life when you left me standing at the altar...

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: And what did you say?

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: How could I be angry at you when clearly what has happened to me is as God intended?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (relieved) Good one!  Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: It happens to be how I feel. Brian sits next to Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: God... Of course.  I'm sorry -- I mean, I'm... (sighs) Brian -- I've got to go.  The man's a lunatic, but I know exactly where he's going next.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: God bless you, Maggie. She turns to rush out, then stops herself.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh, wait, my purse. She moves to the confessional, knocks, then speaks to Mrs MAGGIE (cont'd) Excuse me, sorry, forgot my purse. Good luck. Maggie closes the booth curtain and turns to Brian. MAGGIE (cont'd) Wait -- what was the ridiculous question he asked? Brian smiles mischievously.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: He wanted to know how you used to like your eggs.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Weird.  Like after all those years you would remem-- She starts to go, then stops in her tracks as she hears:

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: (interrupting) -- Scrambled, with salt, pepper and dill.  Same as me. Maggie  looks at Brian.  Suddenly, she remembers too.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (tenderly) I'm really sorry that I hurt you, Brian.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: I'm happy here, where I'm supposed to be.  But if you ever become a Catholic, may I ask you a favor, Maggie?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: BRIAN
dialogues.text: Could your confess to Father Patrick from now on?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Of course. And she scampers out.  Brian goes back into the confessio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie drives up to an old brick firehouse that is now an garage.  The faded sign reads: "Gill's Garage".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie rushes inside and looks around.  No one is in sigh Several cars, including a yellow jeep-like car up on a hy lift, are in the funky garage.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Gill?  Lydia?  Gill? A CRASH, coming from the nearby back room, we hear loud m in Spanish, then out stumbles GILL CHAVEZ, 34, wearing a stained Grateful Dead tie-dyed T-shirt.  He grins triumph worshipfully cradling a CASSETTE TAPE in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: GILL
dialogues.text: Hey -- I found it! Maggie regards her former fiance with patient warmth.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Found what? Gill looks up and gives Maggie a fond, hazy smile.

dialogues.speaker: GILL
dialogues.text: Mags!  Hey, look -- The tape from the Radio City Music Hall concert -- Remember that night I as trying to get Jerry to let me sit in on "Ripple"? He pulls out the cassette from its case.  It's broken.  T is dangling from the cassette. GILL (cont'd) (disappointed) Oh, I'll play it for you. Gill picks up an electric GUITAR and starts to play.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (shouts over the music) Listen, Gill -- There's this reporter who's ben making my life a living hell ... If he comes by here, don't talk to him.  And whatever yo do.... (crosses to Gill) ... Don't show him that picture of me at the concert in San Francisco -- Suddenly, a loud CHUCKLING emanates from the car overhead MAGGIE (cont'd) What was that? Maggie stops Gill from playing.  She shoots her ex an ang and moves a lever on the shop wall.  With a HUM, the car

dialogues.speaker: GILL
dialogues.text: We went to San Francisco twice. Remember one time we had a flat tire... Which picture? As the hydraulic lift slows, the car is lowered, revealin sitting in the driver's seat.  He has been enjoying the photograph he's holding.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (feigning shock) Imagine!  Maggie Carpenter topless in a public arena. (checks photo again) And I see there was a chill in the air. Maggie swipes for the photo, but Ike is faster at pulling

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Give me that!

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: But the most interesting thing here is that I don't see the rose tattoo that I've heard about on your back. Gill takes off his guitar and sets it down.

dialogues.speaker: GILL
dialogues.text: Ike bet me fifty bucks you don't still have it, Mags.  I said "You're on, man! Maggie loved that thing!"  And I could really use fifty bucks. Maggie is conspicuously silent. GILL (cont'd) (looking worried) Mags?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I'm not gonna show you guys anything. I am a soon-to-be-married woman.  Now give me that photograph. Maggie seethes.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Sure, I would love to give this to you. Just give us one quick gander at that rose, and, I'll gladly hand it over. She tries to grab the photo again.  Ike pulls it away.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Fine.  Here. Maggie quickly turns around and pulls down the back of he revealing the top of her back and a pristine expanse of s tattoo. MAGGIE (cont'd) (turning back around) Satisfied?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Completely. Gill is still trying to grasp the meaning of this.

dialogues.speaker: GILL
dialogues.text: Maggie?  You got it removed?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Gill, I'll go ya double or nothing if was a stick-on.

dialogues.speaker: GILL
dialogues.text: (dismayed) Maggie?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (admitting) I'm really, really afraid of needles... It doesn't make me a bad person. Ike laughs.  Maggie looks at him with rage.  Gill dramati pulls down the front of his t-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: GILL
dialogues.text: Look. There it is on Gill's chest: the rose tattoo.  Maggie sig pained.  Gill shows it to Ike.  Ike looks at the tattoo. shakes his head at Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (sincerely) Look, look, man.  I think the man is heartbroken.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: He is not! Maggie moves the lever on the wall again, sending Ike bac the ceiling in the car.  She grabs the photo from Ike and

dialogues.speaker: GILL
dialogues.text: I think I am. Gill grabs his guitar and sits. GILL (cont'd) Hey, Ike, what would Jerry do? The hydraulic lift stops moving.  Ike leans out.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Jerry.  He'd play.  He'd play... Jerry would play his heart out. Ike sings and taps along in tempo on the side of the car sings and plays "Ripple".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Maggie drives into town with Peggy, they see Ike on po SHERIFF, POLICE CHIEF and MAIL    MAN, all playing instru a blues band.  Ike is not bad on slide guitar.  They all Ike. Maggie "CHUFFAS" with Peggy and moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The slow, loopy pitch of a softball.  A bat connects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big wholesome man, CORY, runs for first base.  He just out the throw.  Bob, acting as umpire, yells, "Safe!"  Ha Cory turns to the stands and waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie and Peggy, cheering loudly.  Peggy tries to whoop than Maggie, but that would be tough.  From firs base, Co back to them.  The two women sit back down and Maggie tak up with their conversation.  Maggie is still al steamed u

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Okay, he's on base.  Can we talk about my life now?  -- Ike's going to turn that tattoo stuff into a big deal -- that I was never serious about Gill, blah blah.  He's totally out to get me.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: For what reason?  Some personal satisfaction?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: That's what he says, but if he thinks that I don't realize he's writing another article, then he's an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: It's probably because you got him fired.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Ya think?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Not that he doesn't deserve to get fired... Look!  Cory's going for second!... Sneaky!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cory as he runs for second base and with a slide beats th for the force out.  The women jump and cheer -- Maggie, a the most boisterous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dennis recognizes Ike as he walks up.  Dennis tells Ike t is going to marry Maggie some day and shows Ike where Mag sitting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie spots Ike as they sit back down.  She groans.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: There he is.  Snoop Doggy-Dogg.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Over there.  Ten o'clock.  He's talking to our little Dennis.  Dennis will turn into one of those "sources say" things.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: He looks better with that stuff out of his hair.  He's an attractive man. Ike finds Maggie in the crowd and leaves Dennis.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I'd say you've been in the sun too long. You handle him, okay?  I could use five minutes off from that creep. Before Peggy can protest, Maggie climbs down off the blea and goes and stands near the dugout near the rest of Cory

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Okay, that's fine.  I can do that. Ike comes up to Peggy.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Hello, Peggy Phleming, "not the ice-skater". Ike indicates the seat next to Peggy.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: (protesting weakly) That's Maggie's seat... Ike sits down comfortably.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: ... And this is Maggie's beer. He starts drinking it.  ON THE FIELD, Cory is getting rea steal third. IKE (cont'd) That your  husband out there?  Cory Phleming, a local radio announcer.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Have you listened to his morning show, "Wake up with ballplayer"?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Not yet.  I had a phlemless morning.  I hear he's a pretty good ballplayer.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: This game is pretty important to him. He made all-stars in high school, you know.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: That must have made you proud. Peggy takes a small sip off her soda.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: He was going with Maggie back then. (quickly) He was never one of her... I mean, they were never going to get... They just dated for a while. Cory dives in for third and makes it.  The crowd goes wil Peggy yells and jumps in. PEGGY (cont'd) Good job, honey! But Maggie's whoop sails out above it all.  Cory waves. at Peggy.  He directs his delight at Maggie, who jumps up down by the dugout. Ike looks between Cory, Maggie and finally, Peggy.  Peggy her waving hand back down to her side and sits down.  Ike pretends not to have noticed.  The two watch as Maggie an smile at each other.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: It's nice that they're still friends.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: (looking at Maggie and Cory) Oh, sure.  That was a long time ago. See, she's not a man-hater at all. She's very supportive of men... Next BATTER hits one to deep left field and it lands in t yard.  Cory scores, greeted by Maggie.  Ike and Peggy wat Cory and Maggie belly-bump and high-five each other in celebration of Cory's play.  No looks at Peggy.  Ike keep empathetic silence, seeing that Peggy is truly hurt. PEGGY (cont'd) I'll be back in a second. Suddenly, Peggy stands, pushes past him and runs down the Maggie looks up just in time to catch Peggy's exit.  Ike his tape recorder out of his pocket and starts speaking i Maggie shoots Ike an accusing look, walks up to him in th bleachers and sits next to him.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You've been here for three minutes. What did you do to her?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: You can turn that finger around. Ike does an on-the-button imitation of Maggie jumping exc at Cory.  Now Maggie sees what he's getting at.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (defensive) You misinterpret everything.  We've all been friends our whole lives.  But that's the types of relationship you wouldn't understand.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Obviously, I'm not the only one who doesn't understand it.  The USS Maggie leaves quite a wake... Excuse me. Ike walks away.  Alone, Maggie tries to seem enthused.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: See, I cheer good.  What is he, a cheer critic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting in front of Inn Hale Bar, we see the BARTENDER pantomiming holding the reins of a wildly galloping horse seen something like this before.  Maggie's wild ride away her last wedding.  Ike laughs with Bartender just as Magg drives by the bar and sees this.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (to herself) This guy never stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie walks up to the front desk of the hotel, where Lee sleeping with his feet up.  She knocks his feet off the c

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Lee, hey, wake up.  Give me the key to the reporter's room.  I want to snoop around.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (handing her the key) Okay.  Second floor.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Don't take anything big. Maggie moves up the stairs towards Ike's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie walks towards Ike's room, checks that no one sees enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie lets herself in the modest room and turns on the l on.  She spots on audio cassette on the desk near the doo holds the cassette up to the light to read the hand-writt label.  It says "Miles Davis" on it.  She pockets the tap walks to the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike has placed post-its on a framed picture, using the fr bulletin board.  Post-it notes lay out the information he gathered under headings and subheadings.  Parents "Mother deceased, subheaded by "Walter" and there is one for "Bri "Gill", and "Bob".  Maggie smiles and shakes her head.  S one post-it down and reads it to herself.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (reads) "How does she get all these guys to propose?  She's not that beautiful." (snorts) Bite me, paper boy. She begins ripping many of other post-it off the picture MAGGIE (cont'd) (as she takes post-its) Rude... She's ripping them down, fast and furious, then shoves th her shoulder bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike comes down hallway as Harvey puts his shoes out to be

dialogues.speaker: BACK INSIDE THE ROOM
dialogues.text: Maggie, looking around, discovers the wedding video on th coffee table and grabs that, too. MAGGIE (cont'd) Thief! THE SOUND OF A KEY IN THE DOOR makes Maggie jump.  She fl the bathroom, and shuts and locks the door.  Just as Ike he sniffs and looks around the room, instantly knowing so is up.  He sees all his notes gone and a glimpse of Maggi closes the bathroom door.  Ike is steaming.  A BUMP sound the bathroom.  He goes over to the door and tries the han It's locked.  He starts to pound on the door.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: All right, I know you're in there... You steal my research... You're messing with the first amendment now.  Open up. Open up.  You got no place to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike's wrong.  Maggie is already trying to open the first bathroom window.  It's stuck.  She climbs over the bathtu opens that window and starts to climb out.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: I want to have a very serious discussion with you as to why you're such a pain in the ass. We HEAR Ike slamming his body against the bathroom door. As Ike breaks in, he runs to the window and yells after h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IKE (cont'd) That's breaking and entering.  I'll call the sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You do that.  And remind him he's bringing the wine to the luau.  Thanks. She disappears around the ledge of the building and runs Ike's neighbor, Harvey, sits reading near his window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON:  A CASSETTE PLAYER.  We see the familiar handwr label: "Miles Davis."  "Kind of Blue" plays as Maggie lis a chair, looking shell-shocked, surrounded by the post-it stole from Ike's room.  We see as she reads them: "Father fisted drinker," "Peggy, best friend, but Peggy doesn't t trust Maggie," "Bob" -- doesn't love him.  Overwhelmed, s finishes reading the last note, leans back, puts her feet the table, deep in the mood of the melancholy music. The CAMERA MOVES on the last note on the floor next to he It reads: "SHOWS NO REMORSE". FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's early morning.  Mrs. Pressman hands Peggy a cup of c to go.  Peggy walks to the beauty parlor, unlocks the fro and goes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy enters and starts about her opening duties.  She tu the lights and turns and sees her friend, Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Do you think I flirt with Cory? Peggy stops in her track.  Maggie is sitting curled up in chair.  She looks like she hasn't slept.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Good morning to you, too.  You look good.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Thank you.  Do you think I flirt with Cory?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Yes. Maggie looks miserable.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I don't mean it. Peggy moves to the salon mirror near Maggie with her cup coffee.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: I know.  I think sometimes you just sort of spaz-out with random excess flirtation energy and it just lands on anything male that moves.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: On anything male that moves?  As opposed to anything male that doesn't move? Peggy pours her coffee out of its Styrofoam cup into a ce

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Like certain kinds of coral. Peggy sits in the salon chair next to Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I'm going to kill myself.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Because you think I'm all like... "Hey man, check me out".

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: (friendly) No, I don't think you're like, "I'm charming and mysterious in a way that even I don't understand and something about me is crying out for protection from a big man like you".  Very hard to compete with.  Especially to us married women who have lost our mystery.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: But you haven't lost your mystery! You're very mysterious!

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: No.  I'm weird.  Weird and mysterious are two different things.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: But I'm weird.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: No.  You're quirky.  Quirky and weird are two different things.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Peggy, there's distinct possibility that I might be profoundly and irreversibly screwed up.  Despite that, I love you and I can promise that I will no longer flirt with Cory, and I beg your forgiveness. Maggie looks ready to cry.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: I'm not worried about you and Cory or Cory and me or even that you're irreversibly screwed up.  But, Maggie, you've been like this since we were kids.  And I think now that you are aware of it and that it hurts people's feelings, maybe it's time to move on with your life and commit to someone of your own, like Bob, if he's the one.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I think you're right. (then) Is there anything I can do to make it up to you?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Something that brings warmth to my heart. (pause) Duckbill platypus.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It's only funny at Camp Birchwood at three in the morning at a tick hunt. It's not anymore. Maggie makes her funny face.  Peggy doesn't laugh.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: You're right.  It's not funny now. Maybe we both grew up.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Thanks.  Will you fix my hair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie exits her house, gets on her bike and rides off to town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike is still in bed.  He slowly blinks awake, stretches, about to  throw off the covers when Maggie's voice breaks silence.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Freeze.  Hold on to those covers -- I didn't come here to see Ike Junior. Maggie smiles cheerfully at Ike from the foot of the bed. narrows his eyes at her.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
