dialogues.text: I take it the desk clerk is one of your many admirers.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (deadpan) How do I do it?  I'm not that beautiful. Ike notices Maggie is holding two coffees.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Coffee.  Now. Maggie hands it to him.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You're welcome.  Your notes made interesting bedtime reading -- if you like trashy fiction.  Your observations are distorted, ungrounded an incomplete. You must be very proud.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: I'm not a boastful man.  What's your point? Ike puts a shirt on as Maggie speaks.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: My point is that one again, you're getting it all wrong.  That won't improve your reputation any, and it's not very flattering to me either.  So, I'm going to give you a chance to write the truth.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Really. Maggie turns away from him as he dresses.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I've decided to cooperate and let you interview me. (beat) For a thousand bucks. Ike clears his throat as he stands putting his pants on. MAGGIE (cont'd) I want a big wedding and a killer dress and for a grand I will answer all your questions and let you follow me around. Ike takes his coffee with him as he picks up his glasses, them on and crosses to the window.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: My magazine doesn't pay because for stories.  It's not what you call ethical.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh, but making up the facts as you go along is ethical?  Actually, I meant you.  You probably got severance or expenses or both.  I'll take your check. No credit cards.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (to Maggie) You've seen the post-its.  I've already got more juicy material than I need. Why should I pay you dollar one?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Because I think you're writing on spec and with a first person interview, you might actually sell that thing. Ike knows she's right.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Too much.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Seven-fifty.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Five hundred.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Six-fifty.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Done. Scowling, he writes out the check and hands it to her.  M looks at it and smile sweetly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike jogs alongside of Maggie on her bike.  Maggie parks h and they go inside her door to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie leads Ike upstairs to her workroom.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Pardon the mess.  I haven't cleaned since the fifth grade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Insert on a cappuccino machine.  We PULL BACK and see Mag Ike standing at her work table.  An automatic cappuccino stands on the table.  Its base is made from a used paint machine.  It looks very shiny and futuristic.  Maggie's l "MAG" is on the side.  The machine shakes as it steams th cappuccino.  Ike notices another homemade machine on the IKE (cont'd) What's this over here?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It's a birthday present for my cousin. Put your finger in.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Cindy the manicurist. He puts his finger in the wrong hole of the machine.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No, the other one. He puts his finger in the correct hole.  She turns it on. brushes rotate.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (laughing) This is wonderful.  You reconfigure all these industrial parts and you do something amazing with it. He looks around and spots some gadgets and lamps on anoth He walks to them. IKE (cont'd) Amazing.  Found industrial stuff. Willow lamp... Rasta lamp... He picks up one of the many logos on the counter.  Each b "MAG" logo. IKE (cont'd) Is this your preferred logo?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: I like it.  This whole thing is pretty incredible. (studying a lamp) I think you could probably sell this lamp idea in New York.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Maybe someday.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: You afraid to try?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (stares at him) No, I'm not afraid.  Just... Maybe someday.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Well, I'm impressed.  Absolutely incredible. (sitting) I didn't expect pink and lacy, but this isn't exactly a woman's room.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What an incredible chauvinistic observation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie's showing Ike engagement rings.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: That's Brian's.  He took me ut canoeing on the lake and gave me the ring in a velvet box. Ike snores.  Maggie hits him. MAGGIE (cont'd) (defensive) It was classic. Maggie hands Ike another ring.  This one is in the shape Grateful Dead rose. MAGGIE (cont'd) Gill.  Of course.  He proposed at the tie-dye t-shirt stand at a Dead concert. It was very sweet until he hallucinated that the drum set was a blood-sucking space alien.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Always a mood killer.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Still sweet. Maggie hands Ike a third ring.  It's in the shape of a bu and studded with multi-color gems. MAGGIE (cont'd) George.  He proposed at a butterfly farm in St. Thomas.  The ring was inside a cocoon.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (grimacing) It's a little "Silence of the Lambs" for me.  I can't believe you waited for the wedding to run.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: He's an entomologist!  I thought it was very unique. Now Maggie shows Ike the ring on her hand.  It's a gold " a diamond set into the number. MAGGIE (cont'd) And here we are at Bob.  He proposed during the seventh inning stretch... Ike touches her hand to examine the ring more closely.  H surprise at his touch shows on her face as she finishes h sentence. MAGGIE (cont'd) ... At an Oriole's game. She takes her hand down.  Ike steps away.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Wait.  Don't tell me.  The scoreboard lit up with "Mary me, Maggie." Ike picks up his cup of cappuccino and moves behind the c

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It was one of the most wonderful moments of my life.  Cal Ripken even applauded.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (stopping) Highly suspect.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?  It was incredibly romantic!

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Maybe it's just me, but -- if you got to dress it up, it doesn't ring true. Ike moves back to the couch. IKE (cont'd) I think the most anybody can honestly say is, "Look..." (sits on the arm of the couch) "I guarantee that we'll have tough times.  I guarantee that at some point one or both of us will want to get out of this thing.  But I also guarantee that if I don't ask you to be  mine, I'll regret it for the rest of my life. Because I know in my heart -- you're the only one for me" Maggie stares at Ike for a beat.  His words have taken a bit of her breath away.  She covers.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I like it. She moves from the fireplace to a chair and sits. MAGGIE (cont'd) I'd like it better on a scoreboard. (lightly) Is that how you proposed when you asked your wife to marry you? Ike is taken aback. MAGGIE (cont'd) Don't look so surprised, you've got divorce written all over you.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: I'm a work in progress.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: So?  Is that what you said to her?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: No.  I think I said something eloquent like, "So, uh -- maybe we should, ya know.  What do you think?"

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Now that's romantic.  A proposal like that and you didn't find eternal bliss? What went wrong? Ike takes a swallow of cappuccino.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You don't know.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Maybe you should ask her some time. Ever thought of that? Ike is restless.  He stands up.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Call me crazy, but I believe that check I gave you entitles me to ask the questions for a while. Ike puts down his cup of coffee, gets his tape recorder a close to Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Fair enough. (thinks a beat) Actually... Maggie move to TV.  She picks up Ike's stolen post-it not her wedding video on top of the TV, and goes to the front MAGGIE (cont'd) I'll just need one more day to make sure your check clears.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Ow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike and Maggie drive in Maggie's truck.  They pull up in a Bridal Shop. A spectacular dress fills the small window.  It's beautif romantic, sexy.  Maggie and Ike can be seen in the reflec

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Even with everything that's happened I've still never been married and I still deserve a beautiful dress.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Agreed. Maggie gives Ike a smile that lights up the sky.  They go

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is fairly large and prosperous, probably the pl go in the Tri-County area.  A little FLOWER GIRL, 10, is fitted on the pedestal in the middle of the room.  A sale POLLY, has taken the flower girl under her wing.  They ar under the expert eyes of a stern looking woman, MRS. WHIT the shop owner.  Also, the girl's MOTHER is there watchin

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: (to the mother) She'll be the prettiest little flower girl in your daughter's wedding.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Mr. Whittenmeyer.  Hi, Polly! The flower girl sees Maggie and runs and hides behind Pol

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: Hi, Maggie.  You'll have to excuse her, Maggie.  Some of the children are afraid of you since you dragged that little boy up the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I didn't drag. (then to the girl) He tripped on his shoelaces. Mrs. Whittenmeyer comes forward to greet Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WHITTENMEYER
dialogues.text: You've come for your dress.  Good! I'll get it from the back. Maggie leads her to the front window.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (happily) Actually, I would like to get this dress. She points to the dress.  She smiles back to Mrs. Whitten expecting her to share her joy.  Mrs. Whittenmeyer darken

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WHITTENMEYER
dialogues.text: (to Polly) Polly, take Leslie into change. (then, to Maggie) But the one you have on hold is lovely.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (pleasantly) Yes.  But I've changed my mind.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WHITTENMEYER
dialogues.text: It's one thousand dollars. Maggie is keenly aware of Ike listening in.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I have one thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WHITTENMEYER
dialogues.text: (firmly) The other one is only three hundred dollars. Maggie lowers her voice, hoping to lessen the humiliation moment.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Is this dress for sale?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WHITTENMEYER
dialogues.text: It just seems like an awful lot of money to spend on one of your dresses, Maggie... You only wear them for about ten minutes. Ike watches with regret as Maggie's child-like enthusiasm drains away, her happy mood crushed by the tactless assau the shop owner.  He's starting to see that it's no always being Maggie. There's a tremor in her voice.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's a good point. (then, sitting) The other dress is nice. Ike calls out to Mrs. Whittenmeyer.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Whittenmeyer.  May I talk to you for a second? She walks over to him. IKE (cont'd) I don't know much about this kind of thing.  I'm from out of town.  You're a salesperson, right?  You're here to sell wedding dresses.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WHITTENMEYER
dialogues.text: (huffy) Yes.  I've been here for thirty years.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Perfect.  Because Miss Carpenter is here to buy one.  But not just any one. She wants that one.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WHITTENMEYER
dialogues.text: It's a thousand dollars! Ike goes over and takes the mannequin out of the window. Whittenmeyer catches the wig as he puts the mannequin und arm. IKE (cont'd) Look, Aunt Bea, we're buying this beautiful dress and anything else she wants or I'm coming back here with a squirt gun filled with India ink. Mrs. Whittenmeyer wilts under Ike's fierce gaze.  She tur Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WHITTENMEYER
dialogues.text: Will he really do that? Maggie gives her a look. MR. WHITTENMEYER (cont'd) (to Maggie) Well, why don't you pick out some accessories while I get this ready, dear.  Polly, will you come help me, please? Polly comes to help carry the mannequin away.

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: (whispering to Mrs. Whittenmeyer) It's a thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WHITTENMEYER
dialogues.text: Shhhh!  The man has ink! Maggie looks gratefully at Ike.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Tough to spend money in this town.

dialogues.speaker: TIME CUT
dialogues.text: Ike sits as he hears Maggie's voice behind him. MAGGIE (o.s.) What do you think? Ike turns around.  Maggie is standing on the pedestal, we the dress and looking unbelievably gorgeous.  She is over to behold and Ike has to struggle to keep his face under

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (stammering) You look... uh... You look fine.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Fine.  The newspaper's upside down. That's better than fine.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Bob will be very happy. She glows.  Then the moment between them is broken as she suddenly remembers something and grabs the veil off her h

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Bob!  I almost forgot!  I have to meet Bob!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a great place -- a major hub of social life in Ha food is greasy and good, Mrs. Pressman is the waitress, a CROWD the essence of what is wonderful about a small town Maggie and Ike sit on the counter.  Mrs. Pressman CHUFFS the luau, then moves around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Mrs. Pressman, I think we're ready to order.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PRESSMAN
dialogues.text: We're out the special because somebody... (indicates COOK with head) ... didn't order enough sausage.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Let me have the garden omelette.  Egg whites only. Ike looks at Maggie.  He'd bet a thousand bucks on what s next.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I'll have the same.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (clears his throat) Of course.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What was that?  I can't order  my eggs without sarcasm?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Neutral corners you two.  You're on the same team now.  Any more fighting and it's fifteen minutes in the penalty box. (gently, to Ike) Maggie's the nicest person you'll ever meet.  But she's always focusing out there.  She's got to start focusing more in here. (taps his chest) That's why she's had some -- whatever you want to call it -- problems in the past. (to Maggie) That's what we're working on -- focus. Right, Maggie?  Focus on Maggie.  Focus on Bob. As Bob has been talking, Ike has been watching Maggie's f The joy seems to have drained out of her.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (quietly) Right.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (to Ike) I lead Maggie through a visualization exercise.  All the sports shrinks use this head stuff.  Visualize the end zone, if you catch my drift. Bob takes out a notepad and hands it to Maggie. BOB (cont'd) Here's today's mantra: "It's an open field to Big Bob."

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Tell me.  When you get to the altar, will you spike the bouquet?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You know, there's no... Before Maggie can finish, Ike intercepts her.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Well, I'm off.  A reporter's work is never done. (heading to the door) Mrs. Pressman, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PRESSMAN
dialogues.text: Tootaloo.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDMA JULIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'd like to explain about the weddings. There are reasons why they didn't come off.  Three weddings, no "I do's".  You can't believe how much cake we were left with.  I should weigh three hundred pounds.  I don't think her father minded spending so much money on booze that nobody drank. We hear Grandma as through the hotel doors, we see Maggie the diner.  She gets a bag from inside the cab of her tru comes inside the hotel where she finds Ike talking to Gra who is having tea with her friend, NETTA.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Ike... Hi, Grandma.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Gram here was going to give me the skinny on why you run from marital bliss.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDMA JULIA
dialogues.text: Right, cover your ears, Netta.  It's not that she's afraid of the wedding, she's afraid of the wedding night. Innocent girls are terrified of "the one-eyed snake". (getting into it) Why, when I was a virgin bride, I took a knitting needle with me into the bed... Ike winces.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Actually, Grandma, I charmed the one- eyed snake awhile ago.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDMA JULIA
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, I forgot.  I'll tell you one thing, your grandpa didn't forget that wedding night. (no Netta) You can take your hands off your ears, Netta.  Your tea's getting cold.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Can you excuse us a minute? (then to Ike) May I have a word with you, please? Maggie moves toward door.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Bye, Netta... Bye, Grandam. He steps over to Maggie in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I found this and didn't know if it was something interesting. Maggie hands Ike a 30-year-old LP: Miles Davis' "Kind of

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (excited) Oh, my God -- It's Miles Davis.  This is "King of Blue"!  This is the original recording.  Hard to find in good condition.  Where did you find this?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (casual) It was in the attic.  It was jus sitting there gathering dust.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: It's valuable.  Hang onto it.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No.  You take it. She steps outside, leaving Ike with the record.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Hmmm... Figuring out what kind of music I like and then finding me a rare album. You're not trying to soften me up, are you?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No -- I'm cleaning an attic.  I wouldn't attempt the impossible. She turns and walks back to the diner where Mrs. Pressman outside watering plants.  Ike looks after Maggie and then down at the record in his hand.  Somehow it makes him sad

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike drives through Hale gobbling french fries from the fa bag in his lap.  Ike passes THE INN HALE BAR, same dump o tavern he talked to bartender at. ANGLE ON: MAGGIE'S CAR parked a few cars down.  He pulls and parks.  He gets out and speaks into his tape recorder

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike approaches the window of the bar.  There's a DRUNK MA DOG sitting outside.  Inside, we see two figures from the arms around each other.  One is definitely Maggie.  The o definitely not Bob.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (coaxing) C'mon.  Let's go. As Maggie helps the man get up,  we see that it's Walter, father -- dead drunk.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: (belligerently) I haven't had any fun since you got your driver's license... They stumble and lurch, exiting the bar toward Maggie's c

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I'm not exactly having fun, either... Steady.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: (to Dog) Good boy, Port Hole.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: His name is Skipper, Dad... Steady.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: I changed it. (then to Drunk) See you later, Mr. Travis. (then to Maggie) That guy has a problem... Maggie, you can run everyone's life but your own. Maggie's having trouble keeping him steady as she opens t door.  Ike is there in a flash to help her pull Walter in car. WALTER (cont'd) Good daughters let their fathers pass out. Walter passes out on the front seat.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (without difficulty) Ike... Please don't write anything about this --

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: No.  Forget about it.  Don't even think about it. Maggie looks at him with real gratitude.  She swings the door shut.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Watch your leg, Dad. (then to Ike) I'm so tired of this.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Why don't you let him sleep it off in the trunk. I'll take you for a ride. Then we'll come back for him. (to Drunk on bench) Keep an eye on him.

dialogues.speaker: DRUNK MAN
dialogues.text: I'm too loaded.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: I was talking to the dog. (turning to Maggie) All right? Maggie thinks about this for a moment.  She takes a deep

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Okay... I'll just grab my jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing of Ike's car driving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie and Ike ride along.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: My dad managed a business and two mistresses.  He wanted me to be a novelist.  More? Maggie nods, IKE (cont'd) My mother wanted me to become a musician.  0 for two.  But at least I'm a journalist and we all know journalism is literature in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike and Maggie stare forward.  Both seem in melancholy mo They're beginning to sense they're in trouble here.  Sudd the car falters and jerks.  It shows to a stop on the sho the road.  The car backfires and smokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike and Maggie sit in the steaming car for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Your filter's clogged.  This takes unleaded.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Can you fix it?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: First I have to find some tools.  I need a half and a nine-six-tenth.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (removing his glasses) Of what?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (in amazement) Wrenches.  My dad's gonna love that one. Maggie slams the food closed.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Kind of isolated.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yeah.  It's kind of nice. An uncomfortable silent pause.  Ike breaks the moment.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: There's one thing we New Yorkers know how to do is hail a cab.  If there's no cab, we walk. Ike stares off down the road.  Maggie indicates a buildin the distance, then turns off the car lights.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I can get some tools over there.... and save the battery... There's one thing we country girls know how to do is cut across a field.  It's quicker. Maggie points diagonally across the field to where a gas sign glows and the lights from the outer house twinkle. He smiles and follows her into the field. MAGGIE (cont'd) Be careful of snakes.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Snakes?  Are you serious?  I don't like snakes.  I've never even seen a snake. He steps carefully into the field, then hops gingerly tow

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Maggie leads Ike through a cornfield.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Do you think there's only one right person for everybody? Ike chooses his words carefully.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: No.  But I think attraction is too often mistaken for rightness. Attraction is very misleading.  And if it's mutual, it's well, terribly distracting.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes it is.  And it doesn't mean anything. Ike nods as they come to a wooden fence.  She puts her ha his shoulder.  Ike puts his hands around her waits to giv boost over the top.  We see the flicker of misunderstandi Maggie's face at the initial contact.  Neither of them mo forward or back, but the electricity is obvious. ANGLE ON:  Ike.  His conflicted feelings are apparent.  W difficulty, Maggie straightens up and they both quickly r their hands. MAGGIE (cont'd) (lightly) I suddenly forgot how to climb a fence. They look at each other for a moment, then:

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE AND IKE
dialogues.text: (breaking the moment jokingly) "Tools". She climbs over the fence on her own and Ike follows.  Th an old guy, LIONEL, whittling on a porch. MAGGIE (cont'd) Lionel, can I borrow some tools?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, we need a half and nine- sixteenths.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Gonna bust out of another wedding?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: You're sure well known around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing shot.

dialogues.speaker: BETWEEN TWO LOCATIONS
dialogues.text: Ike sits on his bed, on the phone, working and eating his breakfast.  He's watching Maggie's wedding tape again.  F is cooking an elaborate breakfast.  Ellie rushes around g ready for work.  He is on the phone to Ike.

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: (into phone) Yes, well, my theory was that she may be running because she gets attention... Negative attention is attention. Like when women whack you on the street because of your column, that's negative attention.

dialogues.speaker: IKE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is about her negative attention, not mine.  Did you get the reimbursement for the dress yet?

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: (into phone) No, I'm paying for the dress.  Do you think she's still gonna run?

dialogues.speaker: IKE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I don't know. Ellie enters the kitchen, hears the question and shakes h to herself.  If only these boys would give it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is finding it very hard to gloat.  Fisher is annoying

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Look -- I'll be in there later today. I'll come by and tell you all about it.

dialogues.speaker: FISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You're coming here?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: FISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Then come for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Okay, we'll order out.

dialogues.speaker: FISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Order out like a Philistine, when you got the Galloping Gourmet here?... Ike hangs up and watches more of the George Swilling wedd video.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bar from the opening scene.  GEORGE SWILLING, the sam Ike talked to before, is sitting on a stool, nursing his He looks better.  Ike enters.  George looks up and recogn Ike, who takes the bar stool next to him.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Get this man a Kamikaze.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Splendid dissection of Maggie Carpenter, very professional job. Ike sits and leans over to George.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (whispers) You could have told me you were fiance number three.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: And end up in the papers?  I've been humiliated enough already to last a lifetime, thank you.  I'm sorry she got you canned.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: She's a cacophony of contradictions.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Well, I'm writing another article on the cacophony.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Ah, can't stay away from her, can you? Like a moth to a flame.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Guess you'd know about that.  You're an entomologist, right?  How's business?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (taking a sip of his drink) Not bad.  I was traveling around studying the reproductive and migratory patterns of locusts when Maggie met me.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Neuter a locust, feed the world.

dialogues.speaker: GORGE
dialogues.text: Not the world.  Just Africa and China. Ike wipes the smirk off his face.  Like Maggie's other me guy has a worthy accomplishment under his belt. GEORGE (cont'd) You know Maggie was the only girl I ever met who would hold my tarantula. On the first date. IKE (cont'd) So, tell me, George, why do you think she ran?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Same as you said.  What did you call her?  A "man-eater", "a devouring death goddess."

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: I don't think that's why she ran.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why do YOU think she ran? Ike sips his drink before answering.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I'm working on it.  I was on the wrong track.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: And you defending her?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: No.  I call it like I see it.  I'm a journalist.  I'm a truth teller.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Unbelievable, she got to you.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Oh, please!

dialogues.speaker: GORGE
dialogues.text: Join the club. (passing him his drink) Here, you need this more than me. George heads out.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (protecting, taking his tape recorder out of his pocket) I'm writing an article, I'm getting paid to do this, it's going to be a cover story, it's going to be published ... The facts will be read someday. As George pauses in the doorway, Ike holds up his tape re IKE (cont'd) What kind of eggs did she like?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Poached, just like me. George exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike walks down a street toward Ellie and Fisher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellie is on the phone as Fisher enters with beer.  Ike si the piano.

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) Overpriced nice apartment and Chinese takeout.  That's New York living.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (into phone) ... Just call me when you have it. (hangs up, then to Fisher) Ike, how is the story coming?  Is she a man-eater?

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: Or a vegetarian?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Or does she pick "NGB'S" -- "Nice Guys, But..."  Nice guys, but I'm cheap. Nice guys, but he lives with his mom... Nice guys, but he just out of prison.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: No... They're interesting guys.  Each one of these guys has something going for him.  I mean, one's been up Everest. Another's become a priest.  One's a pretty good guitar player.  And this guy today tried to end world hunger, if you can believe that...

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: Whoa, Ike.  Getting a complex, buddy?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Fisher, let him talk.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (sits) But one of those guys -- not one of them -- knew her at all.  Each one was convinced that she was perfect for them, but they didn't see her.  And she never showed up so they couldn't see her. It's a very symbolic thing happening. She becomes what she thinks they wanted to be. Fisher doesn't like the sound of this.  He glances at Ell is looking very interested.

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: (in shock) Ike is turning sensitive and I can't bear to watch.  I'm going to make a fresh pot of tea. The phone rings as Fisher exits.  Ike goes to the piano a picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Yeah... Oh, Jay... Okay... Bye. (hangs up, then yells to Fisher) Fisher, don't forget the fortune cookies. She joins Ike at the piano.  Ike gets serious.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Is that what I did to you?  Is that what happened?  Did I just not see you?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: No.  No, you didn't. He hugs her.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (heartfelt) Well -- I'm sorry, I'm really sorry, Ellie.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, too. (beat) Wow.  That only took us between years to say. Ellie blinks back sentimental tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear Hawaiian music.  We see a truck with GUESTS drive HULA DANCERS through barn slats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a small barn that's been converted into a luau with A BAND plays for two hula dancers.  The Trouts had decora as a little slice of Hawaii.  There are tiki lights, nume rented plastic palm trees and fiberglass copies of Hawaii statuary.  Strings of colored lights crisscross the ceili It looks like a Hawaiian high school gym on prom night. Maggie's family, Mrs. Trout and people we've already met, more, are here, milling around wit tropical drinks garnis with umbrellas.  Plastic leis abound and most people have managed to find their old Hawaiian shirts. As we come in, the hula dancers finish their applause and Trout announces.  Hula dancers stop.

dialogues.speaker: LOU TROUT
dialogues.text: Welcome to our annual country luau.  As you know, Betty and I got married on the rim of the crater, Diamond Head.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. TROUT
dialogues.text: (grabbing the microphone) This year, we're dedicating our first dance to the soon-to-be newlyweds, the King and Queen of Hawaii, Maggie and Bob. The couple enters.  Bob is a goody bronzed god in his Kin Kamahamela outfit.  Maggie is spectacular in her authenti looking Hawaiian Princess get-up.  But her face reflects of the festivities around her.  Every now and then, she l and glances around for Ike, hating herself for it. MRS. TROUT (cont'd) King and Queen, dance. Maggie and Bob start to dance as the Quarter sings "Aloha MRS. TROUT (cont'd) Everybody dance. Everybody dances.

dialogues.speaker: TIMES OUT
dialogues.text: Maggie and Bob pose for pictures with some of the guests.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. TROUT
dialogues.text: Pictures of the King and Queen. Dennis poses with Maggie.  Cory poses with Bob.  Mrs. Tro out of film and goes to get more, leaving Peggy and Maggi Peggy whispers to Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Lighten up, wahine.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Lighten up, what?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: This party is for you and Bob.  Get your mind off the reporter.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I haven't seen him in twenty-four hours. It just gives me the creeps a little bit. I'd feel better if I knew where he was.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: (nods to door) Would it? ANGLE ON:  Ike just entering the party.  At least he trie He's got a tropical sheet wrapped around his pants and sh He walks to the bar and is greeted warmly by Lee.  Maggie very flustered. PEGGY (cont'd) What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (after a beat) I'm going to go dance with Bob. Because he's the man. (referring to her headdress) I like those grapes. Maggie dances affectionately with Bob as Mr. Trout, tendi bar, greets Ike.

dialogues.speaker: LOU TROUT
dialogues.text: Hey, Mr. Graham, welcome to our luau. What can I get you?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: You got something without a toy in it?

dialogues.speaker: A LITTLE LATER
dialogues.text: A pair of expressive pantomime "A Little Grass Shack".

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK TO REVEAL
dialogues.text: Mrs. Trout is on stage, introducing hula contestants.  Gr judges the Hawaiian dancing.  The party is at full tilt - little wild, a little goofy.  Some guests (Bob, Cindy, Co and Ted) do the limbo.  Walter, Mrs. Pressman doesn't tur she hears him.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Aloha.  That's a very fetching headdress you're wearing. Ike leans into Maggie, enjoying the smell of her hair.  S notices, but acts casual.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Where did you disappear to?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Missed me bad, huh?

dialogues.speaker: TIME CUT
dialogues.text: All the guests start banding their pineapple cups.  Walte unsteadily, lifting his pineapple.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. TROUT
dialogues.text: Attention.  Listen to Walter.  Listen close, he slurs. (then) Shut up, wahines!

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: In the tradition that has grown through the years, it is now Toast Time!  First up, our host, "A Honey of a Beekeeper", Lou Trout.. Lou Trout stands with his glass raised.

dialogues.speaker: LOUT TROUT
dialogues.text: May the groom's heart be filled with hopes and the bride's feet be filled with lead! There are shouts of "Hear hear!"  Walter roars.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. TROUT
dialogues.text: May the pitter-patter of little feet not be Maggie's.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PRESSMAN
dialogues.text: May the gifts be returned!

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: May the back of the dress be as pretty as the front! The laughter swells and swells, led by Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike watches as Maggie takes the heat, raising her glass a with the others.  Bob raises his glass like the good spor Ike can't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: You know the old saying, "You're not losing a daughter..."  Well, I'd like to! Walter gets a bit laugh.  He goes again. WALTER (cont'd) Maggie may not be Hale's longest running joke... (under her breath) Maggie finishes the punchline along with his father.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER AND MAGGIE
dialogues.text: -- But she's certainly the fastest. Uproarious laughter.  Maggie looks terribly pained.  Ike' enough.  He pushes himself to his feet.  Walter is thrill shushes the CROWD. WALTER (cont'd) Oh, look, Mr. Graham, how about a toast?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: I don't know, give me a minute. (to Maggie) Are you all right with this?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Are you all right with this?  You think this is funny?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: I don't and I don't think you should...

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: It's a joke.  They're kidding.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER AND CROWD
dialogues.text: (yell) Come on and give us a toast.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: You want me to make a toast?  Okay... I'll give you a toast.  To Maggie's family and friends.  May you find yourselves the bull's eye of an easy target.  May you be publicly flogged for all of your bad choices and may your noses to rubbed in all of your mistakes... Ike watches their reaction.  The silence is deafening.  A guests stare at Maggie.  Mortified, she holds back tears.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. TROUT
dialogues.text: That was funny. (a pause) But enough toasts, let's hula.  Let's start the music up. She gets everyone up to hula.  Band plays fast tune.  Mag walks through the CROWD down the steps and outside.  Ike follows, but Peggy grabs a coat for her.  Bob watches her Cory approaches.

dialogues.speaker: CORY
dialogues.text: Hey, Bob.  I got twenty dollars bet on--

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Not now. Bob rushes after Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: (calling after her) Maggie.  Maggie. (to Ike,  handing him a jacket) Here.  She may need this.  It's not really Hawaii. Ike exits.  Then, Bob comes over.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Where'd Maggie go?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Oh, she just went to get me something from the car. Cory comes over with Dennis to Bob and Peggy.  BOB/PEGGY/ DENNIS CHUFFA:  About Bart Starr and football.  (Which ke from going outside to follow Maggie).  Bob thinks about i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike runs after Maggie.  He grabs her arm and turns her to

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: I'm the only goddamn person in there pulling for you.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You humiliated me!

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: No, Maggie, I defended you. Humiliating you is what everyone else is doing.  It's the theme of this party.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I had it under control.  Now they feel sorry for me.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Well, they should.  Because they're about to watch you hang yourself again. Maggie has no response. IKE (cont'd) -- Tell me something, do you really care about Mount Everest?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It's fun!  It's high.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Or the sexual habits of locusts?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: That was very interesting research George was doing!

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: What kind of Dead Head gets a temporary tattoo?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I already explained about that.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: And where you ever really going to run the leper colony in Molokai?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (wincing) Brian told you that?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Or maybe you just wanted to wear the headdress.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Every one of those times I was being supportive.  Something you won't understand.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Supportive?  You weren't being supportive.  You were being scared. Just like now.  You are the most lost woman I have ever laid eyes on.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Lost!

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: That's right.  You're so lost you don't even know how you like your eggs.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What!?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: With the priest, you liked them scrambled.  With the Dead Head, fried. With the bug guy, poached.  Now it's egg whites only, thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: That's called changing your mind.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: No, that's called not having a mind of your own.  What are you doing, Maggie? You really want to let that man drag you up Annapuma on your honeymoon?  You don't want to climb Annapuma.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes I do!

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: No you don't.  You want a man who will lead you down the beach with his head over your eyes just so you can discover the feel of the sand under your feet. You want a guy who will take you into a cave with a thousand candles just to read you a poem.  You want a man to wake you up at dawn because he's burning to talk to you and he can't wait another minute to find out what you'll say.  Am I right? He's laid her flat.  Maggie can't speak. IKE (cont'd) Am I right? She fights back angry tears.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Stop.  Stop it!  I'm getting married on Sunday, and you're just trying to make me run!  Why?  Because you're a cynical, exploitative, mean-hearted creep who wouldn't know real love if it bit him in the armpit!  And all you do is tear other people down and-and-and laugh at them, and criticize what they do, because you're too afraid to do anything yourself!  I read your column. You never wrote one about you.  I'm not the only one who's lost and you know it! Am I right?  Well?  Am I right? ANGLE ON:  Bob comes outside.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Mag.  Help me out here.  Green Bay. Right guard. Both Maggie and Ike are breathing hard.  Bob comes up to and gives Ike a very hard look as he puts his arm around fiancee. BOB (cont'd) You know... Blocked Bart Starr, crewcut ... Are you okay? Maggie adjusts her face as best she can.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Let me take you back inside, okay? She lets him lead her away.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Jerry Kramer. Ike looks at her drooped shoulder and he shakes his head walks to his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy and Cindy arrive for the rehearsal.  They leave Cin dog in Peggy's car and walk to the church.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Tell me, why does Maggie need another wedding rehearsal and two days before the wedding?  She's already done this.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Bob is making her visualize the ceremony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are in the church proper now.  Peggy waits in a pew leads Maggie and Ike up the back steps of the church.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (to Maggie) Okay, we're ready.  Want me to have Ike leave now? Maggie turns on Ike with "cheerful" hostility.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No.  No -- Actually, let's make Ike the pastor.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: I'd rather not.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) Come on, it'll give you a great view. It's perfect. (seeing Peggy) Hey. Maggie smiles at Bob.  Ike sighs and goes with it.  Bob p to the head of the aisle and places him.  Peggy follows M into the foyer to get ready.  Cindy sits with Ted at the

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Team effort, Pastor Ike... Cindy, ready? (after no response) Cindy, come on. Cindy leaves to join the girls in the foyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once in the privacy of the foyer, Peggy and Maggie talk.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: He's going to be the pastor?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yep.  I want him to be front and center and to watch everything.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: What happened at the luau?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (flustered) ... I don't even want to talk about the luau. (then seeing a hanging rope) What's this?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: It's for the bell. Cindy joins them.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Bob's in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Don't be nervous, Maggie.  Let us visualize.  Remember what Bob said? "Be the ball."

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: "Sink the putt."

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: "Make the shot."

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: "Nothing but net."

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: "Never say die." Maggie puts her hands up.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Go! Peggy and Cindy exit.  Maggie pulls the bell rope and swa and forth as she rings the bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is Maggie's turn to enter.  They all turn expectantly. much time passes.  Ted plays the organ, then stops.  Magg swings back and forth in the foyer doorway.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Honey, are you okay? Maggie stops ringing the bell and pulls herself together. walks into the aisle looking a little shaky.  She takes a tremulous steps slowly with her eyes closed, peeking occasionally with one eye.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (taking off his jacket) At this pace, it could be an evening wedding.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Hold it!  Hold it!  I think we're taking this too fast. He begins to pace. BOB (cont'd) We need to limber you up a little. You're tensing. (thinks a moment; to Ike, moving him to groom's spot) You stand here and be me so she knows how far she'll have to go. (then to Maggie) I'm going to walk with you. Bob goes to Maggie and walks behind her. BOB (cont'd) Visualize!  Visualize!  It's game time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie walking. BOB (cont'd) You are the football.  You're spiraling through the air towards the hands of the groom. She proceeds down the aisle.  Bob behind her.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (eyes down) Yes, I'm spiraling through the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie raises her eyes and sees Ike in front of her as gr Ike and Maggie lock gazes.  If they had to, they couldn't away.  All the things unspoken are now communicated -- th the longing. MAGGIE (cont'd) I streak towards the goal line. Maggie's pace quickens. MAGGIE (cont'd) And I land on the goal line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob beams to see Maggie's eager arrival at Ike's side.  H switches off the music and proceeds like a proud coach to pastor.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm the pastor.  Dearly beloved, blah, blah, blah.  So on and so forth. Ra ta ta ta.  Yabada dabada.  I now pronounce you man and wife.  Kiss the bride, badum dum. (then moving toward Ted) We have the crescendo that leads to us right back down the aisle and out the... Ike kisses Maggie.  It is a world class, Olympic kiss.  I kiss that changes everything and can never be taken back. a kiss you only get once in your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob's smile dies.  Cindy's mouth drops open as the kiss g and on.  Peggy loses control and screams. BOB (cont'd) Maggie!!!!? Like a bucket of water thrown on two dogs, Ike and Maggie startled out of their kiss.  They pull apart and smile at other. ANGLE ON:  Bob. BOB (cont'd) (furious) If you were imagining me, you did great. (to Ike) What the hell were you doing?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (eyes on Maggie) I'm sorry, Bob.  She kissed me back.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (dazed but happy) I kissed him back.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Yeah, I caught that.  Want to tell me how long this has been going on? Maggie looks at Ike, wondrous, confused.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: About a minute...?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: A little longer for me.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What do you expect me to say to this?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: How about -- "I hope you'll be very happy together"? Bob hauls back and punches Ike in the face.  Ike drops.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I hope you'll be very happy together. Bob storms down the aisle and out of the church.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (to Peggy) Take care of him. Maggie leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob is halfway down the walk.  Maggie appears at the chur and calls after him.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Bob, I'm sorry! (half to herself) At least I backed out before the wedding.  That's progress! He keeps marching.  Now Peggy appears next to Maggie.  Ma calls again. MAGGIE (cont'd) Some woman is going to make you a lot happier than I ever could... The words are barely out of her mouth when Cindy comes ou door, racing after Bob at a full sprint. MAGGIE (cont'd) See?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Well, Maggie -- in the words of Mrs. Pressman: "Holy moly".  Call me later. Peggy goes to her car.  Cindy joins her as Bob speeds off car.  Now Ike takes Peggy's place next to Maggie.  Maggie to face Ike.  They are both beet red, stammering and unab look at each other, trying to act normal.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Okay.  So... what, uh... What just happened?  Just now?  Jus then?  In there?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I, uh -- I frankly don't even want to talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Me, either. Ike GRABS Maggie and BOOM -- they are all over each other kissing frantically, tongues, hands, hair, elbow, you nam Blathering fools.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (blathering) I love you.  I love you.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (blathering) I love you, too. They come up for air.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Wait.  We have to talk.  We have to do some talking now.  Pull up a railing. Maggie sits on the railing, then Ike backs up and sits on opposite railing. IKE (cont'd) You have to go down an aisle and say "I do".  You have to get married.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: To who?  Are you asking me?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Me? Ike backs up to opposite railing and sits facing Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Yes, you!

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (thinks) Well, you do have the dress.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: And the church.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: And the wedding date.  There's the two of us. (beat) So, you think... maybe... You have to go down the aisle with somebody you love and who love you back.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I'm okay with that.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: So am I.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: So, we'll... They both nod and sit there smiling, sort of. The organis closes the church door.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Good night. Ike pulls his tape recorder out of his pocket and quietly into it.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: I'm getting married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They smile at each other and remain sitting.  Then, silen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike drives up and parks in front of the hotel as he talks cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellie's on the phone.  Fisher sits nearby.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Ike's going to get married. Fisher throws himself onto the carpet and rolls himself helpless with laughter. ELLIE (cont'd) (without turning to him) Fisher, if you pee on that Persian, I'll kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie talks to Peggy, Cindy and Grandma Julia.  Grandma sits under a hair dryer.  Sprout, the dog, sits in his ba

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: I love his eyes.  I just believe they're listening to you.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: His hair... any color.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDMA JULIA
dialogues.text: I like his tight butt. Peggy laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Grandma!

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: (to Cindy) See, this is a mature relationship. She's really found it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike and Maggie fishing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They play ping-pong.  They laugh, enjoying the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike and Maggie have fun playing cards.  The game is slapj

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie and Ike horseback riding.  They sit on their horse amongst trees, "nuzzling".  Ike reads as he pushes Maggie tire swing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike and Maggie open and close a Hoberman ball by holding opposite ends in their teeth.  Grandma looks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a fire in the fireplace.  Maggie and Ike sit as shows Maggie some passages from his favorite books.  He's reading something from Yeats at the moment.  They seem ha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a media circus including FOUR REPORTERS, Midday wit Meredith and the T-shirt Vendor.  Plus three other people reporters are interviewing, a GERMAN LADY, BUTCH KENAN, a farmer and Grandma Julia.  Reporter DINA NAPOLI walks dow church steps.

dialogues.speaker: DINA NAPOLI, (OF WBAL)
dialogues.text: Wedding bells are ringing for the fourth time today in Hale, Maryland. Maggie Carpenter, "Always a Bride -- Never a Bridesmaid", will be attempting to complete her fourth wedding ceremony. We'll come back on the air when the results are in.  Back to you, Jessica. Meredith, the low-end public access TV reporter, films hi pointing a cheap video camera himself.

dialogues.speaker: MEREDITH
dialogues.text: The turnout for this morning's wedding is usually reserved for royalty or Hollywood stars, but Maggie Carpenter is Hale, Maryland's special star and the citizens of Hale are out in full force today. The NY T-shirt Vendor pitches his wares.

dialogues.speaker: T-SHIRT VENDOR
dialogues.text: I got "Bye-bye Birdie".  "What part of 'I do' don't you understand?"... Get your "Runaway Bride" T-shirts here... Reporter JULIE MURPHY stands near Grandma Julia and Mrs. Pressman. JULIE MURPHY (Channel 6) The bride's been here for almost an hour, but being around in the beginning was never her problem.  We'll be here, showing you the full wedding ceremony, we hope. Reporter JACKI and TIFFANY stand at the edge of the CROWD reporting.

dialogues.speaker: JACKI/REPORTER
dialogues.text: Will she or won't she?  That is on the minds of these several hundreds folks, who are standing here this morning. Not to mention on the mind of Groom Number #4, ex-USA Today columnist, Ike Graham, who is missing in action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT window of church.  Peggy peers out the window at t carnival scene.  Cindy sits with Maggie as she leans forw doubled over on a child's chair.  Peggy moves from the wi sit with them.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (moves to window) He's not coming.  Watch.  He's not coming.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: No, no.  I saw eight geese flying in a "V".

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You and your lucky geese.  You always see geese.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Not eight...

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: And in a "V".

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Eight is good... "V" could be Victory. They ad lib various words starting with the letter "V". is nervous.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Rub your ears.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Yes, rubbing your ears is very soothing. Cory does that to me when I hyperventilate. Maggie rubs her ears.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: We do it to our dog.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It's hurting.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: We'll rub. After they rub Maggie's ears a bit:

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: He's here!  He's here! They all squeeze and peer out window.  They scream in exc Cindy rushes to Maggie's wedding dress.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: I'll get the dress.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: He's here!... He's here!

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Now's the time for calm... If you don't calm down, you won't get your dress on... (reassuringly) He's the one... He's the one. Peggy moves to help Cindy with the dress.  Maggie stands the window a moment.  She picks up a toy horse.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: This is not a good sign. Maggie goes over to Peggy and Cindy, and starts to get in bridal gown.  They continue to ad lib words standing with letter "V".

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: We have to hurry.  The Sunday School kids will be here soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike pulls up slowly.  GUESTS peer through the his car win wave.  Ike rubs his headache.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE MURPHY
dialogues.text: Well, the groom just pulled up.  There was talk of a "now show", but he is here.

dialogues.speaker: DINA NAPOLI
dialogues.text: Ike Graham is here!

dialogues.speaker: IKE'SPOV
dialogues.text: He moves as he takes it all in:  a FAMILY eats a fast foo on a neighbor's lawn, invited GUESTS flock by in their pa best, and local NEWS TEAMS block the way.  The STATE SENA making a speech welcoming the press to Maryland.  A large of reporters head up the church's stairs, hauling their equipment.  They enter the flood of PEOPLE streaming insi church.  Ike snaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike stops the car where it is and jumps out, slamming the anger.  The REPORTERS swarm around him as he gets out of They continue to pound him with questions as he walks to steps.  An OLDER LADY smacks him on the shoulder with a newspaper.  He turns in astonishment and continues up the steps.  He charges up the stairs and grabs Lee.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Shoot ours so she has one with an ending. Mrs. Pressman stands, shooting Ike with her video camera. IKE (cont'd) (pleading) Mrs. Pressman, please.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PRESSMAN
dialogues.text: It's okay.  There's no microphone. You're no fun.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: No, I'm not. Ike retreats into the church.  Lee comes up to him again video camera:  CHUFFA about Scorsese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Fisher and Ellie sign the guest book, a LOCAL LADY sta Ellie.  Ellie stares back at her until she leaves.  Ike w away from Lee and turns smack into Ellie and Fisher.  Ike his arms around them and gives them a big hug.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Friends.  Thank you.  Thank you. Over Ellie's shoulder, Ike sees Fisher's grinning face. IKE (cont'd) We are friends, aren't we, Fisher?

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: (grinning) Of course we are.  Of course.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Then you'll be my best man.

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: Well, I'm good, I don't know if I'm best.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Go talk to the pastor and he'll tell you what to do.  And someone will tell me what to do.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: You always looked great in that suit... And Ike? (emotional) I'm happy for you, honey. Ellie whispers in his ear. ELLIE (cont'd) I'll have a car around the back to whisk you out of here if she runs. Ellie kisses him on the cheek and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob comes up to Ike.  He looks like he's going to punch I abruptly holds out a rose boutonniere.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You look awful.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) Thank you. Bob hands the flower to Ike.  Ike is shaking.  Bob catche and looks up to Ike.  It is a moment of clean honesty bet men.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Ike.  Need help? He takes the boutonniere and puts it on Ike's lapel. BOB (cont'd) I'm glad it's you.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I didn't want to find out I wasn't for her in the fourth quarter.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Got any last minute advice?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (motioning to their eyes) Maintain eye contact. Bob turns and leaves, going down a side staircase.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (to himself) Eye contact.  Eye contact. Out of the corner of his eye, Ike sees a pictures of Chri wall.  He leans into the picture and whispers. IKE (cont'd) Cover me. He walks into the chapel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike steps up and stands next to Fisher.

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: (to Ike) I have no idea what I'm doing.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Your job is... the ring. (to Fisher) Do you have the ring?!

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: I just found out I'm best man!  I'm lucky I have a suit... What's wrong? Ike gives the ring to Fisher.  The Pastor approaches Ike. turns away and look out over the guests. IKE'SPOV:  There are most of the TOWNSPEOPLE we've come t know, plus some NEW YORKERS for Ike, with little ponytail Armani wire rims, Donna Karan bodysuits.  There's a lot o smirking, checking out the hicks, forming their stories f cocktail hour.  Elaine is in back all dressed in black, m Ike.  Mrs. Trout approaches Ike.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. TROUT
dialogues.text: You should thank Lou and I for the wedding car -- a '63 Buick.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. TROUT
dialogues.text: Oh, come on.  You're practically family. Mrs. Trout starts picking lint off Fisher's jacket.

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: Hello.  I'm Fisher.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. TROUT
dialogues.text: This doesn't want to come out.

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: You just pull a hair from my neck.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Trout, go back to your seat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy joins Maggie, who is blowing bubblegum and swaying front of an oscillating fan.  Grandma and Walter come in. Grandma gives her a kiss on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDMA JULIA
dialogues.text: Good luck, Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Grandma. Grandma leaves.  Walter steps up.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: (quietly to Maggie) I'm really rooting for this one.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Dad. Peggy turns off the fan.  Cindy takes the bag from Maggie

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Spit. Maggie spits her bubblegum into the bag.  Peggy hands Mag bouquet.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No sauntering down the aisle.  Just make time.  Let's just get there. Cindy and Peggy nod and leave.  The door closes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both extends his hand to Elaine.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Elaine from New York.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Hello.  I'm Bob, Maggie's fourth attempt.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: That's okay.  There's a lid for every pot.  Besides, I'm comfortable with Ike. I mean, Jack Dempsey lost his heavyweight title to a New Yorker.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: I know.  Gene Tunney. The organ begins to play.  The organist is Ted.  Grandma, Mrs. Pressman and the Trouts watch.  Mrs. Trout picks lin her husband's jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cindy and Peggy enter with the confident air of people wh done this before.  They make it to the head of the aisle quickly.  Peggy gives Ike a wink and an encouraging smile

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and Dennis sticks his head in.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: They're ready, Maggie.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Just a second. Dennis closes the door behind him as he goes back into th chapel.  Maggie has a moment alone.  She looks at back do possible escape route, then changes her mind.  She signal start of the wedding by knocking on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Immediately, Cory and Dennis open the doors for her entra All the guests stand as Maggie enter the chapel smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The aisle stretches before her into infinity.  Faces gogg her from every direction.  The tiny figure of Ike stands beacon a long way off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She plunges forward with a sped-up hesitation step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike rocks imperceptibly, urging her on.  Peggy and Cindy little "come on" motions.  It seems to be working.  Maggi approaches rapidly.  The CROWD has turned from skepticism looks and noises of encouragement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then her feet gradually begin to slow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fisher gives a little "darn, so close" look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Ike is too busy maintaining eye contact.  His eyes ur Maggie closer -- loving her, willing her on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie stops her walk, gives Ike a teasing smile, and the resumes with her walk toward him.  His face.  Her face. face.  Her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her foot inches forward.  The other follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sigh now rises from the GUESTS as Maggie closes in on I smiles at her.  She smiles at him.  She is almost there.. there, smiling at Ike.  The Pastor gestures to the guests down.  They do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike sneezes.  She looks down and imagines she sees the ca splitting apart.  And she bolts like a bat out of hell! flurry of white, she is halfway down the aisle before Ike what hits him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike stands there dazed.  For a second.  Then she springs action, charging after her.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (yelling out) Block the doors! Like a general, he points to Dennis and Cory in the back sends them into action.  The doors shut in Maggie's face. she's a wild animal cornered.   She moves to the side.  T TOWNSPEOPLE stand so Ike can hurry through the pew.  Ike on the pews towards her as GUEST crowd the aisle, blockin path.  Like a gazelle, she leaps to the side aisle and sc down and away.  Fisher gets on his cell phone.  Ike charg one of the full pews, crosses the aisle and leaps across near the staircase to cut her off.  He grabs her veil and comes off in his hands.  Maggie disappears down the steps church basement.  Ike fumble with the veil and jumps over railing, landing on Dennis' toe.  He follows down the sta after her.  Mrs. Pressman and Walter exchange bet money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie comes down steps and enters the church children's school class.  A lot of KIDS And TEACHERS are doing relig arts and crafts.  As Maggie runs through:

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: There's a man coming down those steps with lots of candy in his pockets.  If you tickle him, he'll give candy. She gives her bouquet to a little GIRL as she goes by.  I down stairs.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Maggie! The KIDS mob him, grabbing his pockets.  Ike fights his w through KIDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie as she's in the church kitchen and hops on counter heads out the window.  The window is wide enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike as he gets to the window, but Maggie is out in drivew

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie flies toward a FedEx truck at next house just leav

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gathers her dress and jumps in as Ike yells from wind then, quickly climbs out onto the lawn as the truck start pull away.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Maggie! Maggie looks back once, tearful and regretful, and disapp inside the truck.  The truck races off. The PHOTOGRAPHERS turn their cameras on Ike, en masse.  H enveloped by a barrage of bright lights. Ellie and Fisher, who have also stepped outside on chapel steps, are looking around as Ike turns around the corner past the church.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Look, he's running after her.

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: Look, he's in pretty good shape.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Poor Ike. They look after the FedEx truck and watch Ike chasing the down the road away from the church.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (running; yells) Maggie!

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Where do you think she's going?

dialogues.speaker: FISHER
dialogues.text: Wherever it is, she'll be there by ten- thirty tomorrow. Cindy, Cory, Peggy and Meredith also rush out of the chur comment on Maggie's runaway.  Further down the road, Ike chases the truck, yelling:

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Maggie! As the truck rounds the bend in the road and disappears, stops and stares alone after the disappearing truck.  A s REPORTERS catch up to him, flashing pictures and asking questions.  Another camera flashes and we cut to:

dialogues.speaker: A NEWSPAPER PHOTO
dialogues.text: Of Ike's stunned face on the cover of the USA Today.  The reads: "Hit and Run:  Runaway Bride Strikes again".  And headlines in other papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kevin, the bartender, reads Jay's column, in the USA Toda entitled "Maggie's Mad Dash".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Various newspaper WORKERS also read Jay's column in the U Today entitled "Maggie Mad Dash" and "Hardware Honey Goes and Bolts" in another newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a night like any other in Hale -- the regular order things has been restored on its quaint streets.  Quartet in front of the hotel.  LEE AND CORY CHUFFA:  About where is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie is sitting, end of a long day.  Peggy sticks her h entrance door.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: You okay?  I'm closing.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I'm just finishing up, too.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Want to go to Butch's for a drink or something?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (interrupting) No, I'm just going to head home.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Okay. Peggy starts to go, then moves close to Maggie. PEGGY (cont'd) (stepping closer and making a "V" with her fingers) You know, I was just thinking about that geese thing.  I think the "V" was half of a "W".  A "W" for...

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Wedding.  Wedding. (holding Maggie's face) You just have to get the rest of your ducks in a row.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Thank you.  You still think that he was....

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Quick.  Very quick. Peggy exits.  Maggie stares, losing herself in thought. VOICE startles her.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: (whispers) Marry me, Maggie. Maggie jumps and turns to see:  DENNIS -- the kid from th school football team, popping up from a low position near counter.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (softly) Hi, Dennis.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: I am going to propose, you know.  I mean, the right way.  Soon as I turn eighteen.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You're sweet, Dennis.  But you've got to go.  I'm closing up.  Here's a candy bar and one for your brother. Dennis takes the candy and starts to go.

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: I'm not giving up.   A person shouldn't give up. Dennis exits.  Maggie is alone.  She turns out the lamp s designed, then on again.  She turns off the other lamp on counter and exits.  We hold on Maggie's designed lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike walks up to his door, carrying his mail and a bag of carryout.  He opens the door and walks into his apartment pets Italics, who sits on his sofa bed.  Without taking o coat, he goes to his keyboard and plays music as he CHUFF his cat about marriage and divorce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad and Grandma Julia are there.  Grandma is making lunch Walter is juggling oranges.  There's glass of beer on the kitchen counter.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: That's Maggie.  Home for lunch.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDMA JULIA
dialogues.text: She's been doing this since the last wedding.  I don't think it's good. Maggie walks in and kisses Grandma on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Hey.  Grandma, what's for lunch?

dialogues.speaker: GRANDMA JULIA
dialogues.text: Turkey and cheese.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Honey, your grandmother and I were thinking about opening a wedding gift museum. Walter laughs.

dialogues.speaker: STOP
dialogues.text: Walter looks at his daughter in surprise.  He's never hea tone like this in her voice before.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (quiet fury) Just stop it.  Don't say another word like that.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: (putting down the oranges) Maggie, it's just a joke...

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No.  It's my life.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: A harmless joke.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No, it's humiliating and you've been doing it since I was a kid.  I don't like it.  Stop.  You may not like having a daughter with problems.  But guess what?  I don't like having a father who's drunk all the time.  I'll eat in my room. Maggie takes a plate and exits.

dialogues.speaker: GRANDMA JULIA
dialogues.text: That needed to be said.  You know -- you're always making jokes about her, so they won't make jokes about your drinking. Walter reacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike goes out on his terrace.  He bounces a basketball.  I doesn't bounce.  He sits on the steps of the patio an sta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie is kickboxing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie is a bit melancholy as she works on her lamps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike quietly sits in bed writing and staring into space th His cat sits on the windowsill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie jumps rope barefooted late at night.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I need a plan... A plan to life... What would Bruce Lee do?  He'd kick some ass...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie in front of plates full of all sorts of types of e scrambled, poached, sunny-side up, Benedict, soft boiled, -- sits on the kitchen counter.  She ties them all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing shot.  Two MEN try to fix the engine of a ta outside the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eke walks by the T-shirt Vendor, goes into a subway stati

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike crosses a busy street where a MAN is being arrested. passing the upscale "Millennium Hardware Store".  He glan the window, looks away, stops and looks again.  The windo display is made up of an assortment of Maggie's lamps.  L "MAG" is on them.  He smiles and walks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike stares out at water as he walks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike walks along sidewalk, crosses street, enters his buil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike opens the door to his apartment and flicks on the lig crosses to hang his coat in the closet.  In the closet mi sees and is stunned to find:  MAGGIE, sitting on the couc holding Italics, the cat.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Hello, Ike. He closes the closet and crosses to his desk.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Don't tell me.  My doorman is one of your many admires... I knew I should have given him a better Christmas gift. Maggie smiles tenuously.  She's more than a little terrif

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I've been making friends with your cat. (then) Is it okay that I'm here?

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: I don't have much choice in the matter now, do I?  But I can't speak for Italics. (to Cat) Traitor! He moves to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I don't blame you for being mad... Ike looks at her.  Apparently the word "mad" is an unders MAGGIE (cont'd) ... Or... furious. Ike looks at her again. MAGGIE (cont'd) ... Irate?  Livid?  How's that? He starts putting cat food in a bowl.  The cat leaves Mag side and starts to east.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: Livid is good.  So what is it, Maggie? You here on business?  I saw your lamps. They're terrific.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: It's something I've always wanted to do. Ike leaves the kitchen, turns on the balcony lights and r the living room from the balcony.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: You actually could make breaking and entering into a new career. (after opening the glass doors) So, what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I wanted to talk to you about why I run or ride away from things. Ike moves away from her and sits on the steps near the ba window, listening.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
dialogues.text: (after sitting) Does it matter?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I think so... When I was walking down the aisle?  I was  walking toward somebody who didn't have any idea who I really was.  And it was only half the other person's fault, because I had done everything to convince him that I was exactly what he wanted.  So it was good that I didn't go through with it because it would have been a lie, but you -- you knew the real me.

dialogues.speaker: IKE
